Yum Brands (YUM) reported strong first-quarter profit growth Wednesday, with its soon-to-be separated China operations showing marked improvement as bidders weigh an acquisition of the unit.Based on the strong results, Yum raised its full-year core operating profit growth guidance to 12%, up from 10% previously.Yum shares climbed 3.8% in extended trading after closing up 0.5% at 82.53 in regular session trading on the stock market today. Yum had formed a nearly eight-month-long cup-with-handle base and rose above the 82.90 buy point intraday Wednesday. The stock now looks to break out on strong volume Thursday.Companywide earnings per share minus one-time items climbed 19% to 95 cents vs. the same quarter a year earlier, beating estimates by 12 cents a share.Revenue of $2.619 billion was essentially flat vs. last year's $2.622 billion, but it missed forecasts for $2.65 billion. Global sales at stores open at least a year rose 2%.Foreign-currency translation negatively impacted operating profit by $28 million, leading to a 12% rise in operating profit to $564 million.CEO Greg Creed said all four of the company's divisions posted positive same-store sales and core operating profit growth."I’m especially encouraged by the continued turnaround of our Pizza Hut U.S. business, which delivered 5% same-store sales growth," he said in a statement.The China division, which accounts for about half of Yum's business, saw system sales increase 6%, or 11% excluding foreign-currency moves. Same-store sales grew 6%. Operating profit jumped 35%.The growth is encouraging ahead of the unit’s spinoff, following food-safety scares in recent years that sent sales plunging."KFC China had an outstanding Chinese New Year bucket promotion leading to 12% same-store sales growth for the quarter,” Creed said.Yum plans to spin off its China restaurants by the end of 2016 and expects to add 600 stores there this year, pushing its total to 7,800. Yum China has an estimated value of $7 billion-$8 billion.An investor group that includes China's sovereign wealth fund China Investment Corp., KKR & Co. (KKR) and Baring Private Equity Asia is in talks to buy a controlling stake in Yum's China unit, according to reports.Creed said the company's plan to spin off its China restaurants business remains on track to close by end of the year.Meanwhile, KFC's system sales dipped 2%, but they rose 5% excluding forex. Comparable sales edged up 1%. Operating profit fell 4%, but adjusted core profit rose 7%.Pizza Hut's system sales increased 1%, or 4% excluding forex, as comp sales climbed 3%. Operating profit improved 7%.Taco Bell's system sales rose 3%, as comps edged up 1%. Operating profit grew 4%.Yum opened 295 new restaurants worldwide, with 72% of international development occurring in emerging markets.The world's largest restaurant company, McDonald's (MCD), is slated to announce Q1 results Friday before the market opens. Consensus is for EPS to rise 15% to $1.16 on a 2.3% decline in revenue against difficult comps.A resurgent McDonald's beat earnings estimates the prior three quarters in a row. Shares edged down 0.2% Wednesday.Among other large, highly-rated restaurant companies, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) -- which is on the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks -- rose to yet another all-time high at 140.01, up 1.8% for the day. Popular drive-in restaurant chain Sonic (SONC) fell 0.9%, and food and games restaurant Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) climbed 1.7% to 40.07.

Investors will get a chance to see how much more sizzle McDonald’s (MCD) can add to its stock price this week when the fast-food king reports first-quarter earnings.The iconic burger chain is already one of the restaurant industry’s top performers this year, with a stock price trading near record highs and an aggressive growth plan that includes a big expansion in Asia.Now all all eyes will be on McDonald’s Q1 results, due Friday morning. Industry watchers expect another strong quarter, at least on the bottom line.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters look for McDonald’s to log a 15% year-over-year earnings gain to $1.16 a share, which would be the third straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth. That hasn’t happened in more than four years.The top-line forecast is a little muddier. McDonald’s overall revenue is seen dipping 3% to $5.8 billion for the quarter, which would be the sixth straight quarter of lower revenue.However, same-store sales growth — a more important industry metric — has been strong. Most analysts see McDonald’s Q1 U.S. comps up 4% to 4.5%.During the 2015 fourth quarter, McDonald’s posted a 5.7% increase in same-store sales, well above consensus. Earnings rose 16% to $1.31 a share, topping forecasts by 8 cents. Sales fell 4% to $6.34 billion, but still topped views for $6.2 billion.The company’s recent financial turnaround is partly the result of success with its all-day breakfast menu, which debuted in the fall. Its McPick 2 for $2 deal, an alternative to the Dollar Menu, didn’t fare as well. It was later replaced by the McPick 2 for $5, which has performed better."While the McPick 2 for $2 and industry conditions were relatively weak in January, McPick 2 for $5, along with ongoing strength from All Day Breakfast, have bolstered sales trends in March," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer noted in a recent report. "We believe that the McPick 2 value brand will be one of several reasons that McDonald’s can sustain (same-store sales momentum)."Meanwhile, McDonald’s said it will begin selling Johnsonville Brats again after a seven-year hiatus, perhaps in response to a recent move by rival Burger King to sell hot dogs.Starting April 25, brats will return to menus at 125 McDonald’s locations in southeast Wisconsin, according to news reports.Another potential growth driver is McDonald’s big expansion in Asia. It recently announced plans to add more than 1,500 locations in China, Hong Kong and South Korea over the next five years. It already has more than 2,800 locations in those markets, most of which are company owned. This time McDonald’s is looking for "strategic partners" to help in its Asia expansion."This will allow McDonald's to accelerate our growth and scale faster across diverse markets, placing us closer to our customers and the communities we serve," CEO Steve Easterbrook said in a statement. "We're in the midst of transforming our business and taking a strategic and thoughtful approach to enhance our ability to grow around the world. These actions build on our turnaround efforts and will advance local ownership, enable faster decision making and achieve restaurant growth."Wall Street seems happy with McDonald’s direction. The company’s stock price set a new high of 128.90 on Monday and is up about 9% since the beginning of the year. McDonald's ended virtually unchanged Tuesday.That’s part of an overall rebound in fast-food stocks. Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) has risen around 13% for 2016; Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) is up 10%; and Wendy’s (WEN) has risen about 2%.Meanwhile, shares of fast-casual stocks such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Shake Shack (SHAK) and Habit Restaurants (HABT) have struggled.

Sector champions wield strong identities, strategies and capabilities. How they rise skyward:Sharpen focus. Many firms don’t know how to harness their own power. That’s the implication from a global survey by Strategy&, a division of consulting giant PricewaterhouseCoopers.It found more than half of senior executives don’t think they have winning strategies.“That’s a concerning figure,” said Paul Leinwand, co-author with Cesare Mainardi of “Strategy That Works.”Another survey of 500-plus senior executives found 90% believed they were missing major market opportunities, and 80% said company strategies were not well understood internally.Soul search. When it comes to scheming to lead, some leaders ask the wrong questions.Instead of focusing outside on areas to grow or markets to seize, a company should look to its core and ask:“Who are we going to be? What few capabilities do we have that nobody else has?” Mainardi told IBD.The trick is delving within.“It’s more of an inside-out approach,” Leinwand said.Power up. Flexing that strategy muscle requires matching a firm’s unique identity with its specific abilities.Those who do -- termed coherent companies by Leinwand and Mainardi -- have:“A way to play” value proposition that distinguishes them from the competition.Distinctive capabilities that allow them to deliver on that proposition.A chosen portfolio of products and services that spring from those capabilities.“The notion is to build a super competitor that shapes the market it’s in,” Mainardi said. “Shape the future rather than respond to it.”Proclaim intentions. Chinese appliance manufacturer Haier Group declared its identity as a top quality provider in dramatic fashion -- with a sledgehammer.“This is a company that for a long time focused on basic quality,” Mainardi said.When a customer complained via letter that a Haier refrigerator wouldn’t stay cool, CEO Zhang Ruimin had employees move 76 similarly faulty units outside the factory, and allowed them to smash the coolers to bits.From then on, “everything that leaves our plant should be a grade 1 product,” Ruimin told workers.The sledgehammer is now displayed at a Beijing museum. “That was a symbol of what he meant,” Mainardi said.Build brawn. Mexico-based cement maker Cemex (CX) strengthened its business by talking with customers.Some wanted help with homebuilding, so the company created its Patrimonio Hoy (Property Today) program. It helps lower-income families with everything from arranging credit via microfinance loans to guiding customers through building regulations.When you work from that core ability, “you don’t fall into the trap of adjacencies that don’t make sense,” Leinwand said.Activate teams. Translating strategy into action can be tricky. “All change is people-powered change,” said Lisa Hillenbrand, co-author with Ellen Auster of “Stragility.”That’s their term for strategic, agile, people-powered change.Elevate them. Fast food firm KFC needed stragility in the 1990s.“The business was really soft and franchisees were incredibly angry,” Hillenbrand said.David Novak -- then KFC president, now executive chairman of parent firm Yum Brands (YUM) -- listened patiently to franchisees. Then he asked them to work in groups on top priorities.Three areas dominated the franchisee discussions -- product quality, menu innovation and training.“Chances are, they’re the same things (Novak) would have come up with anyway,” Hillenbrand said.What he gained was unity.“It went from being his plan to (the team's) plan,” she said.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Pizza stocks Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and Papa John's (PZZA) jumped Wednesday as an analyst sees pizza deliveries faring well amid civil unrest.In afternoon action in the stock market today, Domino's Pizza rose 1% to 136.89, just below a 137.12 buy point after rising as high as 137.87.Domino's is slated to report second quarter earnings on Thursday. Analyst consensus is for Q2 earnings per share to rise 16% to 94 cents and revenue to grow 9.25 to $533.44 million. Domino's has missed Wall Street's earnings target in two of the last three quarters.Papa John's jumped as much as 4% after KeyBanc Capital Markets upgraded its stock to overweight from sector weight and raised its price target to 80. KeyBanc said in a client note that people may be eating at home more often, and munching on delivered comfort foods like pizza amid civil unrest and a contentious presidential election race. Papa John's, which is in the midst of a long consolidation, climbed 3.15% to 71.30 Wednesday, clearing resistance near 70.Among other restaurants, Restaurant Brands International (QSR), which operates Burger King and coffee-and-doughnuts chain Tim Hortons in more than 100 countries, was also breaking out Wednesday from a flat base with a 44.06 buy point. Restaurant Brands shot as much as 3% to an all-time high at 44.93 before settling to a 2.3% gain at 44.50.Burger King rival McDonald's (MCD) eased 0.35% to 126.06 and Jack-in-the-Box (JACK) climbed 1.4% to 89.13, hitting an 11-month high.Yum Brands (YUM), which operates Pizza Hut as well as KFC and Taco Bell, rose 0.35% to 87.87.The Retail-Restaurants group, ranked a weak 151 on IBD's list of 197 industries, has traded in a narrow range since mid-March but on Tuesday rose above its 200-day average and continued climbing on Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Several restaurant operators report quarterly financials Thursday. Check out earnings previews on highly rated Starbucks and fallen leader Chipotle Mexican Grill.

McDonald's (MCD) said Wednesday that it will add McMuffins, McGriddles and biscuit sandwiches to its All Day Breakfast menu nationwide in September, amid concerns about whether the company's recent sales growth is sustainable as it approaches some tough year-over-year comparisons.Shares dipped 0.1% to 120.63 in the stock market today. The stock is making its way through a flat base and has drifted below its 50-day line since May.The stock has gotten a huge lift since All Day Breakfast was introduced last fall, demonstrating to investors that the company could change and turn around flagging sales after a weak 2014.In the years prior to the launch, McDonald's lost customers to Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and other fast-casual chains tapping into a growing preference for higher-quality or healthier ingredients.But some analysts have questioned whether the burger giant has relied too much on All Day Breakfast for its sales growth. Others say the menu expansion could help prop up sales, but not tremendously."It's a positive, but it won't have nearly the same impact that the initial All Day Breakfast launch had," Morningstar analyst R.J. Hottovy told IBD.IBD'S TAKE: McDonald's stock is in the midst of a consolidation, but below its 50-day moving average, a sign of weakness. Investors should wait for MCD to build the right side of a base and form a proper entry point before making any moves.Analysts have also worried about slowing industry sales amid broader economic uncertainty. Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski last month downgraded McDonald's, citing the tough comparisons and saying the U.S. restaurant industry "could remain sluggish for the remainder of 2016".Chipotle shares climbed 1.1%. Wendy's (WEN) rose 0.5%, Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (RBI) added 1.3%, and Yum Brands (YUM) rallied 1.4%.

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Earnings season kicks off with reports from Alcoa (AA), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C). Amazon (AMZN) is holding its second annual Amazon Prime Day. Boeing (BA) and rival Airbus (EADSY) will compete for deals at the Farnborough Airshow, though the Lockheed Martin (LMT)…

Shares of McDonald's (MCD) and Wendy's (WEN) fell Wednesday after Nomura downgraded both stocks to neutral, saying the burger business overall was no longer "a beacon of brightness for the industry.""With the U.S. restaurant industry looking like it could remain sluggish for the remainder of 2016, and McDonald's starting to lap tougher comparisons in Q4 . . . , we believe MCD stock is more likely to be range-bound for the rest of this year," Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski said in a research note, in which he cut McDonald's price target to 129 from 142."While we applaud changes that management continues to make (e.g., testing of fresh beef and actions to reduce costs), we believe that a neutral rating is more appropriate at this time," Kalinowski said.mcdThe McDonald's downgrade echoes concerns from some other analysts that the burger chain's sales rebound last year depended a little too much on All Day Breakfast, which was launched nationwide in October. RBC last month said the improved sales showed the "heavy lifting" done by All Day Breakfast.Meanwhile, same-store sales industrywide have weakened in the second quarter, possibly due to growing consumer anxiety, bad weather or an abundance of competitive discount offerings spurred by cheap food costs.Also, burger chains like McDonald's and Wendy's, in general, face more competition from the likes of Shake Shack (SHAK), Five Guys, In-N-Out and others who put more of a focus on higher-quality ingredients.Kalinowski estimated that comps for burger chains were just "barely positive" in the second quarter. "No longer is the burger segment a beacon of brightness for the industry, as it was in Q1."He added that a data breach affecting more than 300 Wendy's restaurants could hurt also hurt its same-store sales. He cut his price target on the stock to 11 from 12.50.McDonald's closed 1.6% lower at to 120.62 on the stock market today, nearing the low end of the flat base it is forming with a 132.06 buy point. Wendy's fell 1.8% to 9.81. Yum Brands (YUM), now Kalinowski's top stock pick, lost 0.5% 83.89 but is still near an 85.89 buy point.Kalinowski also brought the pain to the pizza industry on Wednesday, downgrading Papa John's (PZZA) and Domino's Pizza (DPZ), citing slower industry trends and more competition from Yum's Pizza Hut.Papa John's fell 0.35%, while Domino's slipped 1.6%.

Starbucks (SBUX) should post another quarter of double-digit earnings and revenue gains, analysts project, but will a good second quarter be good enough for investors?The coffee shop chain is expected to post 18% profit growth to 39 cents a share on a 10% revenue rise to $5.03 billion, when it reports results after the close Thursday.Shares have been consolidating since November, largely trading above their 50-day and 200-day moving averages for the last month. Starbucks shares rose 0.6% to 60.89  in the stock market today.IBD's Take: How healthy are the shares of Starbucks and its rivals? Find out at IBD Stock Checkup"We continue to view SBUX as a best-in-class operator and an industry leader in the increasingly important realm of technology-driven consumer engagement," wrote Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh on Monday. He has an equal-weight rating and 56 price target on the stock.Starbucks' rewards program boasted 11.1 million active U.S. members as of January, with its mobile app accounting for over a fifth of all domestic transactions and with its order-ahead feature also picking up steam.Consensus estimates for domestic same-store sales and global comps are 7% and 6.5%, respectively, according to his report.Piper Jaffray, which noted in its semiannual teen survey last week that Starbucks was still No. 1 with young people, said its latest channel checks leave the firm "confident that Starbucks is well-positioned to continue driving strong same-store sales trends in 2016," citing well-received food and drink offerings and targeted promotions.But with expectations high for the coffee titan, a solid quarterly report may not impress."(E)ven if Starbucks reports good results -- based on lofty investors’ expectations -- the shares may still face some added pressure, as good results may not be good enough to support SBUX’s shares at current levels," wrote Deutsche Bank analyst Brett Levy on Friday. He has a hold rating on the stock.Starbucks is a member of IBD's Retail-Restaurants industry group, which includes Dunkin' Brands (DNKN), McDonald's (MCD), Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) and the beleaguered Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).Yum is slated to report Wednesday.

Chipotle Mexican Grill’s (CMG) series of food-borne illness outbreaks may have cost the company three years of earnings growth, according to JPMorgan’s estimates. But the bank sounded bullish as it upgraded the beleaguered restaurant chain to overweight from neutral."In all, our call is based on Chipotle being a highly meaningful brand that with time and expense can regain customer trust," wrote JPMorgan analyst John Ivankoe on Thursday.Shares closed 2.55% higher but remain below their 50-day moving average. The stock has been trading below its 200-day since losing support at the level in late October, and is 40% off its all-time high.The E. coli and norovirus episodes that hit Chipotle locations across the country also hit its brand image, with same-store sales down 14.6% in Q4 and an expected loss in Q1, the latter of which would mark a first for the company’s quarterly results."We expect normal earnings growth to resume by F18 -- after nearly doubling in F17 -- and believe 20%+ EPS growth can be sustained through at least F20," said Ivankoe.He is not the only analyst who sees the light at the end of the tunnel for the burrito chain.Piper Jaffray’s latest semiannual teen survey found that Chipotle still holds major sway over America’s young people. The firm is positive on the company’s long-term story as well, with an overweight rating and 590 price target.The stock is a member of IBD’s Retail-Restaurants industry group, which is at No. 75 among IBD’s Industry Sub-Group Rankings, joined by Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM) and others.RELATED:Starbucks Is Still Tops With Teens, Chipotle Hangs OnWhy Chipotle Mexican Grill May Have Reached ‘Peak Burrito’

Restaurant Brands International (QSR) shares are looking tastier, while Domino's Pizza (DPZ) is going cold after both companies reported earnings Thursday.The Burger King and Tim Hortons parent earned 30 cents a share, well above views for 22 cents a share, on $918.5 million in revenue, short of forecasts for $932.3 million. That represents a 67% profit tumble on a 1% revenue decline from last year, according to Thomson Reuters data.Burger King same-store sales rose 4.6%, while Tim Hortons comps grew 5.6% in constant currency."It appears as though BK has weathered the storm of competitive discounting during Q1 with its own value platforms, namely 2 for $5 and 10 for $1.49 nuggets, while new innovation including hot dogs likely also contributed somewhat," wrote RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.The fast-food realm has seen a proliferation of super-cheap promotion deals, including Wendy's (WEN) "4 for $4" deal and McDonald's (MCD) recently ended "McPick 2 for $5" promotion.Restaurant Brands shares closed up 1.1%, nearing buy range after loitering in a broad area of consolidation since last August. McDonald's edged down 0.3%, Wendy's dipped 0.5%, and Jack In The Box (JACK) eased 0.4%.Meanwhile, Domino's Q1 earnings per share grew 10% to 89 cents on 7% revenue growth to $539.2 million, missing estimates for 98 cents in EPS on $545.6 million in sales. Currency headwinds weighed on results.U.S. comps grew 6.4%, while international comps rose 7.9%.Shares nearly 10%, slicing below their 50-day line. Pizza rival Papa John's (PZZA) lost 2.7%, and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) fell 1.3%.Dunkin' Brands' (DNKN) per-share earnings rose 10% to 44 cents, beating by a penny, on 2% revenue growth to $189.8 million, edging above views for $188 million.Demands for breakfast sandwiches and beverages fueled 2% in same-store sales growth at U.S. Dunkin' Donuts, above analyst estimates. Baskin-Robbins' domestic comps rose 5%."As (Q1 same-store sales) results for the Dunkin' U.S. segment were ahead of our expectations, we continue to believe sustained SSS trends is likely" through 2016 and 2017, wrote Palmer in a separate report.Dunkin' reaffirmed full-year guidance for 4%-6% revenue growth and $2.20-$2.22 in per-share profit.Amid the success of Starbucks' (SBUX) mobile-order-and-pay service, in which customers can order ahead and pick up in store, Dunkin' also announced Thursday the rollout of "on-the-go ordering" for loyalty program members in New York City, starting in just a few weeks. The company had started testing the service in select cities late last year.Dunkin' shares closed down 0.8% as they form a wide cup-with-handle base. Starbucks also lost 0.8%.

Cooking-equipment maker Middleby (MIDD) spent a good part of last year trying to address a troubling situation: 75 reports that gas ranges made by Viking, the high-end oven maker it bought some three years ago, were turning on by themselves. Viking recalled around 60,000 ovens due to those reports, and Middleby -- which makes cooking appliances for homes and restaurants -- stresses those ovens were made prior to the acquisition. But the recall heightened problems within Viking that weighed on Middleby's finances. Among them: Delays in refrigeration products Middleby had been trying to make more energy-efficient, concerns about Viking's residential products and questions over whether the $380 million Middleby paid was too much for a company seen as lacking new ideas or sufficient margins.For Middleby officials, quality concerns of this magnitude are not what they're used to encountering."Papa John's (PZZA) runs our oven almost 18 to 20 hours a day -- especially on weekends," Chief Executive Selim Bassoul told IBD. "And it cannot break down. It is not allowed to break down."Yet shares of Middleby are up around 32% since February as the company turns out sales growth that outpaces competitors and works aggressively -- and to a large extent effectively, some analysts say -- to turn Viking around. The company has a 98 Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99. That sales growth has been led by an array of kitchen items that cater to more selective home chefs and a competitive restaurant industry, which has been set on international expansion and on serving food in a way that's quicker, fresher and more cost-effective.Roth Capital analyst Tony Brenner wrote in a research note last month that new product introductions addressing increased speed, energy and labor saving "should continue to play a key role in increasing sales and margins." Those gains would also come as the bar rises for service, even within fast food.  An array of big restaurant chains are customers of Middleby -- Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD), Wendy's (WEN), Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and Yum Brands' (YUM) KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell -- along with higher-end chains. Want an oven that can cook a pizza in 90 seconds or a steamer that saves water by utilizing the food's moisture? Middleby has those. Need an oven that can make a steak look and taste like it was fussed over by a chef, or an oven system that can do the work of a line cook or two? Middleby has some of those too.Middleby has a lot of those things in no small part because of acquisitions. It has made more than 40 since 2000, according to the Great Lakes Review stock-picking service, with most of those deals coming during Bassoul's tenure. "He never sits on his laurels," Elliott Schlang, Great Lakes' founder, said of Bassoul. "He's always doing something new and innovative, to broaden his product line and to give the restauranteur what he needs."Restaurants, Bassoul said, face greater demand for breakfast, potentially requiring adjustments to space in the kitchen and on the grill. Greater demand for delivery and analytics, he said, will necessitate more connected, automated cooking equipment. And higher employee wages -- as have been demanded industrywide -- are inevitable."It's going to happen," he said. After reaching an intraday high of 127 on June 8, shares slipped below their 50-day moving average Friday in light of the U.K. Brexit selloff. Shares ended Monday trading around 110. That means restaurants will likely seek technology in place of people. The company's Kitchen of the Future, a conveyor-oven system with an infrared broiler and warming cabinet, helps restaurants get more usage out of each square foot. The system also uses technology that cuts usage of oven burners when not in use.    "This array replaces convection ovens, fryers, microwaves, grills, charbroilers and salamanders (broiler units), prepares food faster and with greater consistency and can eliminate two or three line cooks from the kitchen," Brenner wrote. Profit margins on such projects, he said, "reportedly exceed 50%."Middleby's ventless cooking equipment saves energy -- and a lot of money -- because it doesn't require a large, bolted-down ventilation system. Since much of a kitchen's layout hinges on where ventilation is located, ventless technology helps kitchens become more flexible with floor space and menus. The company's holding trays can also control for moisture and heat, enabling restaurants to keep items fresher for longer and served quickly."People have a tendency to think this stuff tastes like airplane food," BB&T analyst Schon Williams said of machine-prepared items. "I've done a lot of taste tests -- and it's improved the taste concept among customers."The company's food and beverage equipment has also helped some restaurants with an international presence to step up their breakfast game, although Middleby wouldn't say who."We have a number of key executives throughout our organization that literally know how to build a store, build a restaurant, build a small-box retail operation, that know how to lay out a kitchen, that actually have done that," COO David Brewer told IBD.And as more people aspire toward the artisanal in their homes, the sophistication in Middleby's commercial operations has made its way into its residential products. Viking plans to launch an oven that, it says, can cook a rack of lamb in four minutes and a 12-pound turkey in 42 minutes.The company could also use design elements from AGA Rangemaster, a U.K. company it acquired that's known for its rustic-chic ovens and cast iron cookers, to make fancy home products even fancier.Management's experience in cooking equipment has also helped during the company's rare moments of difficulty, as with the Viking acquisition.After that acquisition, the company deployed scores of engineers to Viking to assess potential problems. In quality tests, they hung weights off of refrigerator doors, which could sometimes fall off, Williams said, and in one instance Bassoul slammed an oven door over and over until it broke.The company strengthened Viking's packaging materials. Following the recall, Middleby has sued former senior staff at Viking, and Middleby's salesforce has worked to reclaim goodwill among dealers and made the wiring of Viking ovens less complicated."That's a hallmark of Middleby, just in terms of reducing the number of parts, reducing complexity whenever possible," Williams said. He later added: "Time and time again they've proven they can restructure all these businesses."Almost all Viking dealers have resumed buying the company's products, Middleby says. As restaurants expand internationally, so will Middleby, and Bassoul hopes to make its Viking residential platform a more global entity.Steel prices, Schlang noted, risk hurting the bottom line if they rise, and the company's food-processing business still lives project to project, analysts say. Brenner also said that Middleby's main competitors are bigger and have deep pockets. Manitowoc (MTW) is among its biggest rivals, but its focus isn't exclusive to food service.Restaurant same-store sales were also sluggish in the second quarter and could lag through the year. But as they try to keep costs down and investors happy, equipment could play just as much of a role as the food in improving what they offer to customers."You can do that in a simple way," Brewer said. "You can put the ketchup on top of the meat patty, you can put ketchup underneath the meat patty, add a pickle -- that maybe gets you a quarter. But eventually you have to bring in a new bread and toast it a different way."

Tesla Motors (TSLA), Solar City (SCTY) and McDonald's (MCD) were downgraded Wednesday, while Nike (NKE) had its price target cut.Analysts weighed in on Tesla and SolarCity after the electric-car maker late Tuesday made a surprise offer to buy the solar energy company in a stock swap valued at roughly $2.7 billion. Tesla offered stock that values SolarCity stock at 26.50 to 28.50 per share. SolarCity shares closed near 21 on Tuesday.Oppenheimer downgraded Tesla to perform from outperform, while Stifel Nicolaus downgraded SolarCity to hold from buy, and Barclays downgraded SolarCity to underweight.

Tesla stock tumbled 10.45% -- its worst loss since May 2014 -- to 196.66, the lowest in more than three months. SolarCity closed up 3.3%, retreating from steeper, early gains. Tesla CEO Elon Musk is also chairman of SolarCity and a top shareholder in the solar power company.Analysts question if Tesla shareholders will support the deal, especially with Musk announcing that he willMcDonald's was downgraded to neutral by Nomura, even though the fast-food chain has received more than six bids for the planned sale of 2,800 restaurants in Hong Kong and mainland China.The bids are valued at about $3 billion, according to Reuters. Normura's top pick in the fast-food field is Yum Brands (YUM), which received a price target boost to 95 from 92.Shares of McDonald's dropped 1.6%, undercutting recent lows to 120.62.Telsey Advisory Group dropped its price target on Nike to 69 from 72. Nike shares -- which ended Tuesday near 55 -- have been steadily falling since the company missed quarterly revenue estimates and issued disappointing guidance in March.Nike reports quarterly results again next Tuesday. Earnings are expected to fall 2%, while revenue is seen rising 6%.Shares fell 0.4% to 54.57.FedEx (FDX) received a price target increase from RBC Capital Markets to 175 from 158 after reporting earnings late Tuesday that beat estimates. The stock had finished near 164 Tuesday.The No. 2 U.S. package shipper earned $3.30 a share, up 24% year over year, as revenue rose 7% to $13 billion. But it sees adjusted EPS for fiscal 2017 of $11.75-$12.25, with the midpoint light vs. consensus estimates for $12.05.Shares gapped down 4.5%, in part because FedEx didn't give guidance that included its just-completed acquisition of European delivery firm TNT Express.

McDonald's (MCD) CEO Steve Easterbrook said Thursday that self-ordering kiosks and other technology were unlikely to result in job cuts and were not "meant as a labor replacement," even as higher wages prompt fast-food rival Wendy's (WEN) to aggressively seek labor-saving technology.Easterbrook's response came at an occasionally tense company shareholder meeting, before which protesters staged demonstrations and demanded McDonald's pay its employees more. He was addressing an attendee who asked the following question:“With all the talk and all the protesters and the $15-an-hour wage, if that is mandated, if the government does raise the minimum wage, do you see McDonald’s substituting capital -- having kiosks where people order, automatic pancake machines and things like that taking the place of workers where people will end up losing jobs because of the higher wages?”Easterbrook said that he saw that technology complementing labor more than replacing it."If we were able to alternate certain non-value-added processes in the restaurant we’ll do that because it’s a smart thing to do," he said. "But then that gives us more opportunity to bring that manpower front-of-house -- we can offer better dining area experience and service experience. So I don’t see it being a risk to job elimination."Still, he said, the jobs themselves could be different."It may change the nature of the jobs in the restaurant, because frankly technology is something that our customers are embracing, whether it’s through their phone or whether through self-order kiosks -- that is a societal trend," he said. "We want to adapt to that, but it’s not actually meant as a labor replacement. We can just re-apportion that labor into more service-orientated roles."Easterbrook's announcement follows Wendy's plans to make kiosks available across its restaurants in the second half of this year, although franchisees don't have to use them. Minimum wage hikes in some areas as well as efforts to attract stronger talent have pushed up Wendy's labor costs, the company said this month on its first-quarter earnings call.President Todd Penegor said then that "we'll continue to invest in technology with things in the front of the house and consumer facing, like customer self-order kiosk, mobile order, mobile pay."McDonald's is testing mobile ordering apps, something that Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell, Starbucks (SBUX), Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and others and others already are doing. New mobile payment services such as Apple (AAPL) Pay, Samsung Pay also are fueling the shift. Such mobile services also substitute for labor, though workers could be shifted elsewhere.Along with higher wages, fast-food restaurants have been squeezed by competition both on value offerings and chains advertising better ingredients. April was a slow month for the restaurant business, possibly due to bad weather in some areas, the discounting and more tepid consumer sentiment, analysts suggest."In addition, we wonder if declining food at home prices have begun to weigh on restaurant demand," RBC analyst David Palmer wrote in a research note last week. "For fast food, we believe recent weakness is increasing resolve to deploy value marketing this summer, which may increase risk of market share losses by those chains with limited marketing scale."McDonald's shares closed up 0.4% on the stock market today. Starbucks edged up 0.25%, Domino's added 1.4% and Apple added 0.8%. Wendy's dipped 0.6% and Yum Brands fell 0.2%.

Private-sector employers continued to hire at a steady rate this month, adding 200,000 jobs after a slightly downward revised 209,300 in February, the ADP National Employment Report.Services firms accounted for 190,900 new hires, the vast bulk of new employment. Manufacturing added 2,600 jobs after losing 8,600 jobs in February. Boeing (BA) said Wednesday it would cut 4,550 jobs.Small firms led the way, adding 85,700 jobs, while large enterprises' net hiring slowed to 38,800. But year-over-year, large firms are adding jobs at the fastest pace since May 2012, while small business hiring is the weakest since mid-2014.Also, franchise employment rose by 22,000 in March and 4.1% vs. a year earlier, largely on restaurant franchise gains.  The National Labor Relations Board and several minimum wage hike efforts are singling out the franchise model used by McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM) and many other fast-food chains.The Labor Department will release its March employment report on Friday. Economists expect to see a rise in nonfarm payrolls, including government jobs, of 210,000. They also expect a rise in hourly earnings and the average workweek, after weekly pay fell a stunning 0.5% last month.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Earnings season kicks into high gear, led by tech giants like Alphabet (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT), industrial heavyweights like General Electric (GE) and General Motors (GM), and leading consumer names like McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX). Oil futures plunged after Sunday's a long-awaited…

There's more than meets the eye to California Gov. Jerry Brown's plan to hike the state minimum wage to $15 an hour — about $3.50 more.Including nonwage costs — payroll taxes, paid sick leave and ObamaCare's employer mandate — minimum compensation for a full-time worker could rise as high as $18.52 an hour by 2022, an IBD analysis finds.Social insurance taxes would add $1.15 an hour to the $15 wage. Three days of paid sick leave now on the books in California would add another 19 cents. And the ObamaCare after-tax fine, now $2,160 per uncovered full-time worker and rising each year, will equate to roughly $2.18 an hour in pretax wages. Adding in workers' compensation insurance and unemployment insurance would push the total close to $19 an hour.One big change from a $15 minimum wage has flown below the radar: Many low-wage workers would no longer qualify for Medicaid. For example, a single mom with one child who worked 32 hours per week would earn more than the 138% of poverty cutoff for expanded Medicaid under ObamaCare, though her child would still qualify. A single adult who works just three full days a week also would exceed the income threshold.To no small degree, the $15 minimum-wage movement is asking low-wage employers to lift their workers up closer to the middle class and to provide a full menu of social benefits on top. It looks like a recipe for trouble, and even Brown may be wary about it, insisting that the governor retain authority to delay wage hikes if the state sees a fall in employment or retail sales, or if the state faces a budget deficit. Brown had little room for maneuver because a $15 wage initiative that qualified for the November ballot looked like a sure winner and would have provided no flexibility if the wage hike started backfiring.One early-warning sign for California's wage experiment was Wal-Mart's (WMT) announcement in January that it would shutter stores in Oakland and Los Angeles and cancel two planned stores in Washington D.C., dealing a blow to three cities on the leading edge of the push for a much higher minimum wage.Before Los Angeles put its minimum wage on a path to $15 an hour, the question of how city employers would respond to the simultaneous imposition of a health insurance mandate was simply ignored. An analysis of the wage hike's labor cost impact by the Institute for Research on Labor and Employment at the University of California, Berkeley, explicitly excluded health insurance — or a mandate penalty. The authors explained: "Health benefits are excluded since ... the costs of the benefits will not change if wages are increased." The Congressional Budget Office came to a different conclusion, finding that the ObamaCare employer mandate would exacerbate the impact of a minimum-wage hike. It estimated that a minimum-wage hike to $10.10 an hour could cost 500,000 jobs."(The) additional cost on employers for some low-wage workers who do not currently have employment-based health insurance ... further boosts the likelihood that employers' savings from reducing the size of their workforces would exceed their adjustment costs," the CBO said.Those adjustment costs might include adding labor-saving technology.Wendy's (WEN) CFO Todd Penegor explained in an August earnings call, "We continue to look at initiatives and how we work to offset any impacts of future wage inflation through technology initiatives, whether that's customer self-order kiosks (or) whether that's automating more in the back of the house in the restaurant."Starbucks (SBUX) and Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell are among the restaurant chains promoting mobile ordering, which reduces the need for cashiers. McDonald's (MCD) is about to start testing mobile apps as well.The truth about the ObamaCare employer mandate is that it hasn't been nearly as much of a burden on businesses as feared, so they haven't had to cut workers' hours below 30 per week in a dramatic way. But the reason is hardly cause for celebration: Employers have figured out how to dodge liability by offering "affordable" coverage that costs much more than their modest-wage workers are likely to pay.That's left millions of modest-wage, full-time workers without affordable coverage options. It's possible that California's embrace of a $15 minimum wage will add to their ranks. But the status quo of full-time workers thrown under the bus by ObamaCare may not hold. If the mandate ever becomes something that can't be easily dodged, minimum-wage employers in California will likely cut work hours in a big way, diluting the promise of a living wage.

Wendy's (WEN) said that self-service ordering kiosks will be made available across its 6,000-plus restaurants in the second half of the year as minimum wage hikes and a tight labor market push up wages.It will be up to franchisees whether to deploy the labor-saving technology, but Wendy's President Todd Penegor did note that some franchise locations have been raising prices to offset wage hikes.McDonald's (MCD) has been testing self-service kiosks. But Wendy's, which has been vocal about embracing labor-saving technology, is launching the biggest potential expansion.Wendy's Penegor said company-operated stores, only about 10% of the total, are seeing wage inflation of 5% to 6%, driven both by the minimum wage and some by the need to offer a competitive wage "to access good labor."It's not surprising that some franchisees might face more of a labor-cost squeeze than company restaurants. All 258 Wendy's restaurants in California, where the minimum wage rose to $10 an hour this year and will gradually rise to $15, are franchise-operated. Likewise, about 75% of 200-plus restaurants in New York are run by franchisees. New York's fast-food industry wage rose to $10.50 in New York City and $9.75 in the rest of the state at the start of 2016, also on the way to $15.Wendy's plans to cut company-owned stores to just 5% of the total.Still, Penegor said that increased customer counts more than price hikes drove the chain's 3.6% same-store sales increase in the first quarter.Although profit exceeded Wall Street estimates, Wendy's shares dived nearly 9% Wednesday because of weak second-quarter sales."We are seeing a bit of a softer overall category in April" relative to the past two quarters, Penegor said on an earnings call, implying more of an industrywide trend than an issue specific to Wendy's.Penegor said the reason for softer growth was hard to pinpoint, but he listed a cautious consumer, tougher spring weather in the Northeast, and a wider gap between the cost of food at home vs. food away from home as possible contributors.While Wendy's management was upbeat about company prospects, noting that it just experienced its first year with a net increase in restaurants since 2010, its downbeat comments about sector growth were contagious. McDonald's eased 1.7% after touching a new record high on Tuesday. Yum Brands (YUM), which owns Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, slipped 2.6% and Restaurant Brands International (QSR) fell 3.4%.For now, Penegor said, wage pressures have been manageable both because of falling commodity prices and better operating leverage due to an increase in customer counts. Still, the company is wary about both wage hikes and a possible recovery in commodity prices and is "working so hard to find efficiencies" so it can deliver "a new QSR experience but at traditional QSR prices."In addition to self-order kiosks, the company is also getting ready to move beyond the testing phase with labor-saving mobile ordering and mobile payment available systemwide by the end of the year. Yum Brands and McDonald's already have mobile ordering apps.

Shares of McDonald’s (MCD) rose Friday after the fast-food giant delivered another robust quarter, driven by the continued success of its all-day breakfast menu, as well as positive results from its McPick initiative.McDonald’s earned $1.23 a share in the first quarter, up 22% vs. a year earlier and 7 cents above consensus analyst views. It was the third straight quarter of double-digit EPS growth -- the first time that’s happened in five years.Quarterly revenue dipped 1% to $5.9 billion but still topped estimates for $5.8 billion. It was the sixth straight year-over-year revenue decline but the smallest drop in that string. Sales would have risen 3% excluding the strong dollar.U.S. same-store sales rose 5.4% year over year, which also beat consensus. Global comps rose 6.2% excluding currency shifts, helped by an extra day due to the leap year.McDonald’s shares rose 2% shortly after the opening bell on the stock market today but soon erased their gains and closed down 0.2%. The stock touched a new intraday high of 129.80 on Wednesday but fell nearly 3% Thursday. Shares broke out of a consolidation to a new high on March 30, but in weak volume.Can McDonald's, Other Quick-Service Franchises Digest $15 Minimum Wage?Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook said in a prepared statement that the turnaround plan McDonald's announced last year is "taking hold." That plan includes the all-day breakfast menu launched in the fall, as well as this year’s McPick 2 for $5 promotion."The ongoing investments we’re making in running great restaurants and delivering what matters most to our customers are beginning to yield sustained positive results," Easterbrook said. "For the quarter, we generated higher sales, revenues and operating income in constant currencies across all business segments."Another element of the turnaround plan has been an aggressive move to refranchise restaurants. Over the past five quarters McDonald’s has refranchised about 700 restaurants, JPMorgan analyst Virginia Chambless noted in a report. That figures includes 200 restaurants during the first quarter.McDonald’s recently announced plans to start selling Johnsonville Brats again after a seven-year hiatus, perhaps in response to a recent move by rival Burger King to sell hot dogs at its restaurants. Starting April 25, brats will return to menus at 125 McDonald’s locations in southeast Wisconsin.Another potential growth driver is McDonald’s expansion in Asia. The company recently said it will add more than 1,500 locations in China, including Hong Kong and South Korea over the next five years. It already has more than 2,800 locations in those markets, most of which are company-owned. This time McDonald’s is looking for "strategic partners" to help in its Asia expansion."This will allow McDonald's to accelerate our growth and scale faster across diverse markets, placing us closer to our customers and the communities we serve," Easterbrook said. "We're in the midst of transforming our business and taking a strategic and thoughtful approach to enhance our ability to grow around the world. These actions build on our turnaround efforts and will advance local ownership, enable faster decision-making and achieve restaurant growth."It might take awhile for McDonald’s ambitious Asia expansion to be completed, however."The company continues to search for a strategic partner in Asia but cautioned the process could take 12 to 18 months," Chambless noted.McDonald’s isn’t the only fast-food chain to enjoy a rebound on Wall Street. Shares of Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) is up 10%, edging higher Friday morning.Shares of Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) have risen about 12% this year. But Yum suffered a reversal Thursday: Shares jumped as much as 4%, breaking out to an eight-month high on strong Q1 earnings and raised guidance. But shares closed down 1% on that day. They fell 0.6% Friday.

Grant Chen's Seattle restaurant netted just $8,856.57 last year after he had to start paying a minimum wage of $11 an hour. Starbucks (SBUX) raked in about $2.8 billion.So here's a puzzle: How can it be that the city's minimum-wage law puts Chen, a decidedly small-time restaurant owner, in the same large-employer category as Starbucks CEO Howard Schulz?You might call it guilt by association. Chen, a second-generation Chinese American, pooled together retirement savings with a few friends, along with loans from family members, and used the money to buy a franchise of a fast-casual chain that could provide the stability of a familiar brand, training and procedures that wouldn't require them to reinvent the wheel.Yet now national chains like McDonald's (MCD) that use the franchise model are under political and legal attack on multiple fronts. Small businesses — many of them minority-owned — are suffering collateral damage.Under the Seattle law, and potentially to a much greater extent under New York state's minimum-wage hike for fast-food outlets, small-business owners are being penalized for their association with large corporations that license out their brands.Discriminating against franchises "paints the cross hairs on a disadvantaged portion of the population that utilizes the franchise model because the barriers to entry are low," Chen wrote in a blog post. The title: "Seattle's $15 Minimum Wage Is Driving My Restaurant Out Of Business."The crackdown on franchising comes even as minority ownership of franchises is surging, providing a tried and true method of democratizing the benefits of capitalism. The latest data from the Census Bureau released late in 2015 show that among businesses with at least 10 employees who operate franchises, 17.5% were minority-owned in 2012, up from 13.8% in 2007. Meanwhile, outside the franchise business, just 10.8% of firms with 10-plus workers were minority-owned.This year, Chen and Starbucks have to pay a minimum of $13 an hour, rising to $15 in 2017, with inflation adjustments thereafter. Smaller employers, those with 500 workers or fewer, get two extra years before they have to pay $15.In New York state, where the minimum-wage just began rising toward $15 an hour for quick-service chains with at least 30 U.S. locations, even small-business operators with a single location are on the hook for the higher wage. Meanwhile, the state's minimum wage for everyone else is $9 an hour, at least for now.The higher New York wage applies to a broad range of limited-service or takeout places, including Starbucks, Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell, Shake Shack (SHAK), Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN), Jamba Juice (JMBA), Wendy's (WEN) and Subway.The earliest consequences of this attack on national franchises are mostly confined to Seattle and New York state. Yet the consequences for the franchise business model could be incredibly far-reaching if courts uphold the National Labor Relations Board decision to designate McDonald's a joint employer of the 90% of its workers who are hired, managed and paid by franchise operators.That case, now being argued before an NLRB administrative law judge in Chicago, could put companies that use the franchise model on the hook for labor violations by the franchisees that operate company-branded restaurants."To protect yourself, you would have to manage the employees," said Andy Puzder, CEO of CKE Restaurants, the company behind chains Carl's Jr. and Hardee's."At that point, the 4% royalty doesn't work anymore," Puzder said, referring to the common 4% of revenue that goes to the franchisor as payment for everything it provides to help a franchise succeed.Further, if the franchisor is found to be a joint employer with its franchisees, that would effectively turn small businesses into large ones and create new liability to provide workers clocking 30 hours a week with health insurance under ObamaCare's employer mandate, says David Kaufmann, whose law firm Kaufmann Gildin & Robbins represents franchise industry employers.But the primary objective in rewriting decades of law and regulations governing the franchise industry is "unionizing workers at franchises," Kaufmann said.Unquestionably, the push to unionize would be easier. Instead of organizing workers at individual franchises or groups of outlets under common ownership, unions could deal directly with the corporations behind the brands.The big flaw in the NLRB's case is that McDonald's, like other big franchisors, doesn't control the workers at its franchise locations and doesn't have the power to tell franchise operators how much to pay in wages. That reality was evident when McDonald's said last year it would raise its starting wage at company-owned locations to $1 above the local minimum wage. Franchise operators were reportedly less than thrilled by the move, likely because their workers wanted the same deal. But they had the ultimate decision.The NLRB joint-employer designation would fundamentally redefine the role of a franchisee, from someone who puts up risk capital and runs a business to make a profit into one among perhaps hundreds or even thousands of middle managers in a corporate empire."The ability to run my own business was the very reason I put my savings on the line to become a franchisee," wrote Amir Siddiqi in a Wall Street Journal op-ed last year.Born in Pakistan, Siddiqi came to the U.S. at age 19 in 1985 and worked as a dishwasher at a Carl's Jr. across the street from his community college. He eventually worked his way up through management of the parent company, then seized the chance to become his own boss, putting up all of his savings and borrowing the rest needed to buy three Carl's Jr. franchises. Now he has more than 40 restaurants and 900 workers, including teenagers and immigrants working their first jobs.Making franchisors joint employers, Siddiqi said, could "destroy a road to the American dream for people who are willing to take some risks for the chance to build a business and a better life."The NLRB's joint-employer rule is expected to wind up before the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and possibly the Supreme Court before it takes effect. Meanwhile, the International Association of Franchises has joined business owners in asking the Supreme Court to invalidate Seattle's discriminatory treatment of franchises. Among the petitioners is Ronald Oh, whose dad fled North Korea as a youngster. Now the family has its livelihood invested in a Holiday Inn Express (IHG) with a few dozen employees."The way to become rich is to put all your eggs in one basket and then watch that basket," Oh said at a hearing on the wage hike, quoting Andrew Carnegie. "This is our basket, and the eggs are the lives of my entire extended family. We are watching that basket carefully."

It's the most exclusive club for financiers in Dallas. With seven Jeffersonian-style buildings and manicured lawns, Old Parkland looks more like a college campus than a hive of private-equity firms, hedge funds, foundations and family offices.But the 9.5-acre site, where an abandoned hospital once stood, is now home to some of the city's wealthiest investors.Old Parkland is the pet project of Harlan Crow, 66, a son of swashbuckling real estate developer Trammell Crow, whose empire was in tatters when he gave up control in the late 1980s. It's also a symbol of a decades-long effort to rebuild the family's legacy. Step inside any of the buildings and you might think you're in a museum, with Rodin sculptures in the hallways, a 17th century antique sofa in a lobby and, on display, a piece of curtain Abraham Lincoln is said to have grabbed after being shot."When I got involved in the late 1980s and early 1990s, it was not really clear that our company was going to survive," Crow said, sitting in a wood-paneled room in his Old Parkland office, just past a Rembrandt Peale portrait of George Washington, a stain on the lapel of Crow's rumpled suit jacket and a piece of white printer paper stuffed haphazardly in a pocket.After nine years of renovation and expansion, the complex is now home to TRT Holdings, owner of Omni Hotels and Gold's Gym; Highside Capital Management, the hedge fund turned family office led by Lee Hobson; an outpost of Boston-based real estate private-equity firm Rockpoint Group; and the investment company of Roger Enrico, former CEO of PepsiCo (PEP). Residency is by invitation only.Statuary GardenAt the center of this financial hub is Crow Holdings, an $8.6 billion investment firm built on the remains of Trammell Crow's real estate empire that included the Dallas Market Center, San Francisco's Embarcadero Center, the Wyndham Hotel chain and thousands of homes. The Wall Street Journal in 1986 called Crow the largest landlord in the U.S.Harlan Crow has spent the past quarter-century making his family wealth about more than the buildings bought and constructed by his father. A prominent Republican contributor and friend of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, Crow hosted a fundraiser at his $39 million home last year for Marco Rubio. He has amassed a collection of historical documents that includes Walter Raleigh's last plea to King James, written a month before his execution in 1618, a memo from Lincoln condemning slavery written before he decided to run for president, and a signed copy of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf."He also has a collection of statues in his backyard that he jokingly calls his "Garden of Evil." There's Vladimir Lenin, Josef Stalin, Mao Zedong and Fidel Castro.Crow said he likes hunting for the best statues from dying regimes, though there's also one of Margaret Thatcher on display.'Wildly Optimistic'"My father was wildly optimistic, and most of what he thought would happen did," Crow said. "I have a little bit of a mentality that the world is dangerous and the only thing you can really do is be morally, mentally and physically strong. The rest of the stuff, well, you just do the best you can."Old Parkland was built on the site of the original Parkland Hospital, which opened in 1894. A new hospital had already been built by the time President Kennedy was shot during a Dallas motorcade in 1963 and rushed to the facility where he pronounced dead, and Old Parkland had been converted into a treatment center for tuberculosis and psychiatric patients.The building fell into disrepair, was covered with graffiti and became a blight on a gentrifying neighborhood five minutes from Dallas's downtown and the same distance from its priciest neighborhood, Highland Park, where Crow lives.Today, Old Parkland charges among the highest office rents in Dallas. It has a restaurant, a barbershop, a gym and a circular underground debate hall. A statue of Alexis de Tocqueville overlooks a central courtyard, and Crow said he plans to install a painting of George W. Bush standing in the wreckage of the World Trade Center towers."There's a feeling of university campus more than an office building," said Ben Weinstein, a managing director at Korenvaes Management, the family office for the founder of hedge fund HBK Investments. He used the campus network to raise money to fund the purchase of Super Chix, a fried-chicken sandwich restaurant concept, from Yum Brands (YUM) in August."It's nice," he said, " to be part of a network that shares."

The Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) brand has taken a beating due to several food-safety scandals, but analysts appear mostly positive on the fast-casual eatery's ability to engineer a turnaround -- eventually.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Monday ended its food-safety probe of Chipotle. But perceptions can take longer to change, and Chipotle late Tuesday warned of a "very difficult" 2016 after reporting sharply weaker fourth-quarter earnings. The company also disclosed it received a new government subpoena as a criminal probe expands.Wedbush analyst Nick Setyan told IBD that the earliest he sees Chipotle sales returning to a pre-food-crisis level is in 2017."Even when they do, we may see a different Chipotle" than the one investors knew before the outbreaks hit, he said, given permanent supply chain changes and food-safety measures. Plus, labor inflation and food cost inflation aren't going to stay static, and the company "is not in a position to take prices up over the next year and a half, two years."Restaurant-level margin percentages have ranged from the mid- to high-20s over the last few years, but Chipotle recorded a 19.6% margin in Q4."Margins look closer to 20% than what they've looked historically, and that makes Chipotle not exceptional where they have been exceptional in the past," said Setyan. He said that brings its valuation into question."Arguably, it now no longer deserves a premium to its restaurant peers," he said.Sales growth already was stalling before the food illness news slammed business. But investors were taken aback by Chipotle's January sales news and forecasts for no profit in the current quarter.Shares fell 2.9% to 461.74 in the stock market today after trading as low as 440.41 intraday.Several other analysts see the light at the end of the tunnel."We are optimistic that margins can begin to recover in 2017, particularly if food-cost inflation remains benign, as we expect," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer wrote in a Wednesday note. "Chipotle's restaurant-level economics remain best-in-class despite recent brand damage."Palmer cited improving throughput, new menu items, catering, mobile ordering and strategic marketing as reasons to believe that Chipotle can return to mid-single-digit comps and 20% earnings growth in the wake of its food-safety issues.Bob Derrington of the Telsey Group projects that same-store sales will turn positive in Q4 of this year. The bar is low for lapping comps, however, as Chipotle posted a 14.6% same-store sales decline for Q4. Wedbush's Setyan also sees positive comps "no sooner than Q4."January comps crashed 36%, Chipotle said late Tuesday.Credit Suisse analysts Jason West and James O'Brien "continue to believe the brand will fully recover," according to a report Wednesday. The bank maintains an outperform rating but lowered its price target to 475 from 530.Bank of America boosted Chipotle's rating to neutral from underperform, citing poll results in which almost one-third of respondents said they still ate at the restaurant as often as they used to. Only about one-tenth had stopped visiting Chipotle.During Tuesday's post-earnings call, Chipotle management said it would be "really hard to predict" a recovery timeline."When we looked at other events, other companies that have gone through something like this. The recovery typically takes four or five quarters or so," Chipotle CFO John Hartung said during the call. But he added that the company won't know until the recovery starts.Yum Brands (YUM) and McDonald's (MCD) restaurants in China were several years ago rocked by food-safety scandals, which pressured sales for a number of quarters. Yum Brands reported a 2% same-store sales gain at its China division late Wednesday as Q4 earnings topped views. Shares fell late after closing fractionally higher.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) rose slightly late despite reporting weaker-than-expected earnings and sales as well as offering light 2016 guidance. Buffalo Wild Wings already closed down 4.2% Wednesday amid reports of a norovirus outbreak at a Kansas location.In the near term, Chipotle has work to do before it gets back on track.Chipotle's Hartung said during the earnings call late Tuesday that it is "likely we will post an EPS that is around break-even for the (first) quarter." Wall Street had expected about $2.08, but analysts were racing to slash targets Wednesday.The beleaguered fast-casual chain, struggling to resuscitate its image after a series of E. coli and norovirus incidents that affected around 200 people total, topped analysts' Q4 earnings views with a 43.5% plunge to $2.17 a share, but revenue fell almost 7% to $997.5 million. Estimates were for $1.01 billion.Chipotle is aggressively ramping up marketing and promotion spending in a bid to win back customers."Near-term, I think they're doing the right thing," said Setyan, "communicating the message that they're sorry for what happened, they're making changes."RELATED:Chipotle Warns Of ‘Very Difficult’ 2016, Sees No Profit In Q1

Here's one data point that doesn't gibe with the complaint that economic gains are increasingly limited to an exclusive club: Minority-owned business ownership has been surging.Among businesses with at least five employees, the percentage with minority owners rose to 13.3% from 9.7% from 2007 to 2012, finds an IBD analysis of the most current data from the Census Department.The rise in minority ownership among businesses operating franchises of established brands has been especially impressive. In 2012, 21.1% of franchise operators with at least five workers had minority owners vs. 15.8% in 2007. Meanwhile, among firms that don't operate franchises, 12.6% had minority owners in 2012, up from 9.3% five years earlier.The jump in minority ownership of franchises helps explain a surge in minority-owned restaurants noted by the National Restaurant Association.The data confirm something that is well understood by many entrepreneurs from diverse backgrounds who have sought to carve out a share of the economic pie: Franchising has provided one of the most accessible and surest paths to business success.Among African-Americans, for example, fully 24% of all businesses with at least 50 workers are engaged in franchising, the new Census data show.Yet this model is increasingly under attack from the political left, which sees franchising as a problem, not a solution. Whereas thousands of minority business owners may see franchising as the best approximation of a golden goose within their reach, the labor movement and its campaign for a $15 minimum wage can't see past their arch-nemesis — the golden arches.In their view, dispersing economic power among franchisers makes it harder to unionize service-industry workers than it would be if labor unions could directly target corporate giants. In that sense, minority-owned franchises are merely an obstacle that must be steamrolled for the greater good.The National Labor Relations Board provided a steamroller suited to the task in designating McDonald's (MCD) a joint-employer of employees who work for franchise-owned locations — about 90% of the restaurant chain's total workforce.McDonald's contends that the designation makes no sense because franchise operators make all decisions involving hiring, firing, pay and work schedules. The company's legal challenge is now being heard by an NLRB administrative judge, but the case may take a few years to play out as it heads next to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and then possibly to the Supreme Court.Beyond facilitating a push to unionize franchises, the joint-employer designation would turn small employers into large ones subject to ObamaCare employer penalties for failing to offer qualifying health coverage to workers clocking at least 30 hours per week. It also would make corporations with deep pockets liable for labor violations of its franchise operators.Together, these factors would put so much strain on franchise operators and their brand-name partners that their agreements — typically 4% of revenue goes to the franchisor in return for training and the benefits of scale and name-recognition — may no longer be viable.That's a risk the left is apparently unconcerned about, as evident in the appeal before the Supreme Court challenging Seattle's discriminatory treatment of franchises. In petitioning justices for a hearing, the International Franchise Association highlighted internal emails among government officials expressing their disapproval of the franchise model.At issue in the case is Seattle's more-rapid phase-in of its minimum wage for franchise businesses, which are considered to be large employers if the chain has more than 500 workers systemwide, even if the franchise operator has a single location.In an email to a fellow city council member, Nick Hanauer explained the reason for treating small-business that operate franchises differently than other small businesses: "The truth is that franchises like Subway and McDonald's really are not very good for our local economy. They are economically extractive, civically corrosive and culturally dilutive."Presumably, one of the reasons that a broad segment of franchising companies has made a concerted effort to increase local minority ownership is to make the business model more of a contributor to local economies.There are other advantages, as well, such as a low cost of capital. In the ObamaCare era, letting others do the hiring also may help limit the cost of the employer mandate.New York, in ordering fast-food companies to pay a $15 minimum wage — phased in by 2019 in New York City and by 2021 statewide — also lumped small franchise operators in with bigger employers.The New York Fast Food Wage Board blasted the franchise industry for a "combination of profits and impoverishment," saying that the industry gets a subsidy in the form of public assistance to its workers.The rule covers a long list of food vendors without table service which have at least 30 locations in the U.S. Among them are Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell, Shake Shack (SHAK), Dunkin' Donuts (DNKN), Jamba Juice (JMBA), Wendy's (WEN) and Subway.Ironically, big franchisors like McDonald's might stand to gain if their franchises raised wages. That's because the typical 4%-of-revenue royalty would rise if the franchise was able to pass along a price hike to customers to cover higher labor costs. Thus, the real gripe with the franchise industry may be a royalty structure that provides an incentive to keep costs down. That's why franchisers may be highly likely to eliminate labor costs by investing in technology if wages rise too high.Image provided by Shutterstock.

All-day breakfast and adjustments in food-prep helped McDonald's (MCD) beat fourth-quarter estimates Monday, indicating the fast-food mainstay’s strategy to compete with newer alternatives is working.U.S. comparable sales, a figure considered pivotal to the company's rebound efforts from years past, surged 5.7%. That was far above Wall Street forecasts for around 3% growth and marked a second consecutive quarterly increase after two years of declines. Milder weather during the quarter also helped."We are demonstrating that our turnaround plan is key to restarting growth and becoming a modern and progressive burger company," said CEO Steve Easterbrook, who took over last March and launched all-day breakfast in October.In a statement, he later added: "As we enter 2016, we expect continued positive top-line momentum across all segments."Shares closed up 0.7% Monday after climbing as much as 3% earlier to touch an intraday high. The stock has rallied more than 30% from a year ago.McDonald's earnings per share during Q4 jumped 16% from a year earlier to $1.31, topping forecasts by 8 cents. Sales fell 4% to $6.34 billion. But the decline, weighed by the strong dollar, wasn't as bad as expected. Analysts had modeled a slip in sales to $6.2 billion.Globally, comps rose 5%. In the company's high-growth markets, operating income jumped 27%, helped by an easier comparison in China, where the company suffered from a food safety scare in 2014 after a supplier sold expired meat to McDonald's and Yum Brands' (YUM) KFC.McDonald's management on an earnings call said it's mulling a sale of part of its stake in the company's struggling Japan business and plans to open 250-plus restaurants in China this year. In Australia, all-day breakfast will launch nationwide this quarter, the company said.As part of its new approach, McDonald's has embraced more natural ingredients, offered deals through its mobile app, and experimented with customizeable burgers. But it was all-day breakfast that dominated the discussion -- and the U.S. comp growth."Our guess is this result implies the chain outperformed the fast-food industry by about 3 (percentage points)," RBC Capital Markets said in a research note. "While input costs have started to turn favorable for McDonald’s (and projected to be down 1-2% in 2016), we believe that All Day Breakfast was also a contributor to lower cost-of-goods percentages."Company-operated restaurant expenses fell 7% during the quarter. Breakfast items are generally cheaper as they relate to cost of sales, noted Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, and beef costs have dropped as cattle herds expand.He also pointed to other changes that likely contributed to the rebound, such as searing beef patties better, toasting buns just before giving burgers to customers, and making the menu board more efficient."I think there’s been a number of operational improvements that they’ve done that have been mostly behind the scenes," Slabaugh told Investor's Business Daily.McDonald's Q4 success comes after years of struggles for the chain, which had suffered as more diners, seeking fresher, higher-quality fare, flocked to fast-casual outlets like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).But Chipotle has had problems of its own, namely a foodborne illness outbreak last year that has forced the company into damage control. Shares of other fast-casual chains and fast-food rivals have also drifted lower, while McDonald's shares have risen in recent weeks.Chipotle closed down 1.9% Monday and have plunged more than 40% since October. Once high-flying Shake Shack (SHAK) has tumbled 59% from its peak.Shares of Yum Brands, Burger King parent Restaurant Brands (QSR), Wendy’s (WEN) and Jack In The Box (JACK) have lost ground too.Piper Jaffray analyst Nicole Miller Regan also noted that some rivals in the sector are only starting to tweak their strategies, while McDonald's is putting its own in place."They spent the last 12-plus months creating strategy, and now they’re executing," she told IBD.
