The retail sector is a big one in IBD’s database, made up of 18…

While much of the media attention in the restaurant industry has focused on the McDonald’s (MCD) financial rebound and Chipotle Mexican Grill’s (CMG) food safety problems, drive-in chain Sonic (SONC) has quietly become one of the sector’s top performers on Wall Street.The company’s shares are up about 7% since the beginning of the year and have risen more than 35% since Feb. 10. In comparison, IBD’s Retail-Restaurant group as a whole has risen about 4% since the beginning of the year and 9% since Feb. 10.Sonic’s stock touched a 52-week high of 36.34 on April 6. The high capped a rally that began a week earlier, when the company beat fiscal second-quarter earnings and revenue views and logged a 6.5% annual gain in same-restaurant sales, or at outlets open more than a year. The latter increase was especially impressive, considering that it came on top of an even bigger gain during the previous year’s second quarter."The clear highlight of the quarter was a better-than-expected systemwide comp of 6.5% against a difficult 11.5% comparison, easily ahead of our estimate of 3% to 4% and consensus of roughly 1.5%," William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia wrote in a research note.Sonic reported results after the close on March 29. The next day, its stock price popped 6%.It was a welcome reaction for a company that has largely flown under the radar in the restaurant sector. Most of the attention has focused on rebounding fast-food stocks such as McDonald’s, Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) and Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR), as well as flailing fast-casual chains like Chipotle, Shake Shack (SHAK) and Habit Restaurants (HABT).McDonald’s has benefited from successful initiatives such as its all-day breakfast menu and its "McPick 2 for $5" promotional deal. Meanwhile, Chipotle continues to feel the fallout from the E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at several of its restaurants.Sonic operates in a kind of middle ground between fast food and fast casual. Like fast-food chains, it focuses on quick service. The main difference is that at some Sonic restaurants, you can have carhops on roller skates deliver your food to your car.Like fast-casual restaurants, Sonic specializes in fresh, made-to-order fare that includes burgers, hot dogs, toaster sandwiches, burritos and various breakfast and side items. It has more than 3,500 locations in 45 states, making it the nation’s largest chain of drive-in restaurants. The drive-in concept separates it from other quick-service restaurant (QSR) brands like McDonald’s, Burger King and Wendy’s (WEN), which offer drive-through but not drive-in service."Sonic represents one of the most highly differentiated QSR brands in the country with a fun, 'retro-future' look that breaks through the clutter in a crowded QSR segment," Jefferies analyst Alexander Slagle noted in a report.Another way in which Sonic differentiates itself is its technology focus. Over the past couple of years, the company has invested heavily in new Point-Of-Service (POS) and Point-Of-Personalized-Service (POPS) platforms, while other chains have focused more on mobile apps.Sonic’s POS platform is designed to improve the order process, cut food and packaging costs, reduce employee waste and theft, and optimize labor so the right amount of staff is on hand at the right time. The POPS platform lets Sonic tailor offers to customers based on their past purchasing history. It also provides on-site redeemable offers to customers.At the end of the second quarter, the POPS platform was in 1,616 locations and was about halfway through its rollout, Zackfia noted. The rollout should be finished by the end of the 2017 calendar year."POPS will facilitate technology and social media initiatives (and) allow for uniquely personalized engagement that we anticipate will be a key driver of future same-store sales momentum, including the systemwide rollout of a mobile app that includes mobile payment," Zackfia said.Although Sonic’s heavy investment in technology has cut into the company’s bottom line, most analysts reckon that it will pay off in the long run."While some investors might have hoped for a little better flow-through to the bottom line given the (same-restaurant sales) upside, the team appears to be making the appropriate investments in the business to continue generating market share gains in the future," Slagle noted.Sonic officials have a similar take. On a second-quarter conference call with analysts, Chief Executive Clifford Hudson said the company’s POS and POPS investments provide an "opportunity to leverage this technology and enhance the customer experience in a way that competitor brands can’t."Even with rising technology costs in recent years, Sonic has done pretty well on the earnings front. It has logged 11 straight quarters of double-digit EPS growth.Earnings came in at 18 cents a share during the fiscal second quarter, which ended Feb. 29. That was up 38% from the prior year and two cents ahead of consensus. Revenue rose 5% to $133.2 million, also topping estimates.Sonic raised its full-year same-store sales growth estimate to a range of 4% to 6% vs. prior guidance of 2% to 4%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Sonic to post earnings of $1.36 a share for the entire fiscal year, which ends in August. That would represent a 24% year-over-year gain. Earnings are seen rising another 14% in fiscal 2017.

Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) move to trademark "Better Burger" didn't just signal a possible new burger chain. It also underscores that Chipotle's core business may have peaked.Chipotle is just starting to recover from a slew of E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at several of its restaurants late last year, with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ending its investigation on Feb. 1. Same-store sales plunged 14.6% in the fourth quarter and were down 26% in February. Chipotle has predicted it would report its first-ever quarterly loss in Q1.The burrito giant should see a rebound in sales from depressed levels. Consumer sentiment regarding Chipotle bottomed in January, according to William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia on Friday, citing her survey  of 800 adults. But while Chipotle's stock also bottomed in January, it hasn't made much of a recovery.IBD's Take: How Healthy Is Chipotle's stock and how does it stack up vs. rivals?But Chipotle's growth was decelerating rapidly, even before the food illness outbreaks. And other industry data also suggest that demand for Mexican food generally is no longer outpacing other types of cuisine.Chipotle is the king of fast casual eateries, as well as the clear leader among similar Tex-Mex chains, such as Jack In The Box (JACK)-owned Qdoba Mexican Eats, privately owned Freebirds World Burrito and more.But the Mexican restaurant sector is maturing, while upscale burger chains are growing in popularity, according to market tracking firm Technomic's President Darren Tristano."When we looked at the market in 2015, sales in the (upscale) 'better burger' category grew 15%. Mexican slowed down to only 7% or 8%," he told IBD. Mexican restaurant growth had also been in the double digits.Take a look at the figures for high-flying burger chain Shake Shack (SHAK). There, sales rose 47%, but that was just $51 million compared with Chipotle's revenue at just under $1 billion in the fourth quarter.Chipotle needs to continue diversifying to grow, Tristano said."When you have such large sales growth, it has to slow down. We saw that with a lot of other fast casuals too," he said.Sandwich and bakery chain Panera Bread (PNRA) used to enjoy double-digit and then high-single-digit same-store growth. But in the fourth quarter, that was reduced to 3.4%.It's not surprising that Chipotle's growth has faltered, but what is astounding is that it stayed so high for so long. In the fourth quarter of 2013, Chipotle's same-store sales rose a robust 9.3% vs. a year earlier. But comparable growth then accelerated every quarter until it peaked at 19.8% in the third quarter of 2014."It was just getting bigger and bigger a few years ago," Argus Research analyst John Staszak said. "Comparisons were getting more difficult."Same-store sales growth cooled to 16.1% in Q4 2014, then to 10.4%, 4.3% and 2.6% in the first three quarters of 2015, respectively. Some of that was due to carnitas shortages as the company sought more humane suppliers.Another factor to consider is that Chipotle's food-illness woes haven't necessarily helped rivals. Jack-In-The-Box's Qdoba reported same-store sales growth slowed to 1.8% in its latest quarter, down from 14% a year earlier.Total U.S. Mexican restaurant sales grew at a 2.9% annual rate from 2010 to 2015, when they reached $38 billion, IBISWorld said in a report. The market tracker forecasts growth will slow to 2.5% a year for the 2015-2020 period.Further, Chipotle and its peers are losing ground when it comes to satisfying the public's appetite for hotter cuisines. Diners still love spicy foods, but that's expanded beyond Mexican and Asian dishes to fare such as KFC's spicy chicken wings and Restaurant Brands International (QSR)-owned Burger King's "Angriest Whopper," which features hot sauce in the bun."People looking for spicy foods might be headed for a Mexican restaurant, but there are many other choices for Americans now," Tristano said.Chipotle has already expanded into the Asian food sector with its ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen restaurants, though it hasn't rapidly increased those locations. It's dipped its toe into the fast-growing custom pizza sector by investing in the Locale pizzeria chain.Despite slowing growth, analysts are still bullish on Chipotle."There is still strong association with the Chipotle brand. People have very short memories" for health scares, said Bonnie Riggs, restaurant analyst for market-tracking firm NPD Group.In addition to eyeing the high-end burger sector, Chipotle at the end of March began testing an expanded drinks menu at a store in its home city of Denver as another way to regain customers and boost same-store sales and margins. Some analysts still see an opportunity to expand into breakfast.And the biggest mid-term source of growth is simply creating more Chipotle locations. The company added 192 stores in 2014 and 229 locations in 2015, with 220-235 planned in 2016.Investors can take heart, however. A restaurant operator that is maturing doesn't necessarily mean a death knell for the stock. Investors can, and usually do, reset expectations.Take a look at Panera, which is trading at-all time highs. There's also the fast-food king, McDonald's (MCD), which has rebounded to record highs, largely over excitement that U.S. same-store sales have turned positive following a long slump.And don't forget that expanding into burgers would bring some symmetry to Chipotle's story. McDonald's, home of the Big Mac, was a big Chipotle investor before divesting its stake.

A year ago, you would have been hard pressed to make a case that fast-food restaurant chains such as McDonald's and Wendy's were better bets for investors than trendy fast-casual outlets like Chipotle Mexican Grill. That's a much easier sell today, given the beating Chipotle has taken, following E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at a number of its eateries, as…

Quality, cleanliness and service. Those are core values on which Harry and Esther Snyder built In-N-Out Burger, the regional fast-food chain that counts celebrity chefs Gordon Ramsey and Thomas Keller among its rabid fans.In-N-Out’s star burns even brighter outside the limelight.With annual sales of over $750 million and a per-store average of over $2 million, In-N-Out’s per-store figures beat those of high-profile national chains.In-N-Out started in 1948 as a tiny hamburger stand in the Baldwin Park suburb of Los Angeles.It now boasts 309 locations in California, Nevada, Utah, Texas, Arizona and Oregon.Despite pleas from customers and Wall Street, In-N-Out has resisted an IPO and franchising, preferring a steady expansion that lets it maintain a close watch on each store’s product and execution.It all goes back to quality, cleanliness, service, “the formula that emerged for the standard of running In-N-Out,” wrote Stacy Perman in “In-N-Out Burger: A Behind-the-Counter Look at the Fast-Food Chain That Breaks All the Rules.” “It was not based on some fancy management methodology — rather, it grew out of Harry’s own instincts and exacting personality.”Harry Snyder (1913-76) was born in Vancouver, British Columbia.He had a hard-scrabble upbringing in Seattle and Santa Monica, Calif., often working odd jobs to help support his parents and older sisters in the wake of his father’s usual unemployment.Not one to hit the books, Harry possessed a strong work ethic. He spent his World War II Army deployment in a series of desk jobs due to a perforated ear drum. After the war in 1945, he worked as a caterer at Fort Lawton in Seattle.Esther Snyder (1920-2006), nee Johnson, also grew up in challenging circumstances, as one of eight children in rural Illinois. Unlike Harry, Esther made a college degree a priority.Working part time and taking care of her ill grandmother, she received a teaching certificate and then enrolled in the women’s arm of the Naval Reserve during World War II.After the war, she moved to Seattle, where she finished her bachelor’s degree in zoology from Seattle Pacific University.At 27, she was managing a restaurant in Fort Lawton where she met Harry, 34. Love struck fast, and they married in 1948. Then it was off to Los Angeles to start their new life, also in the food arena.The pair settled in fast-growing Baldwin Park near Los Angeles.While at Fort Lawton, Harry had noticed the increasing popularity of the boxed lunches he delivered. In L.A., he saw the postwar appetite for independence and pleasure and imagined the car becoming a larger aspect of California life.He noticed that Baldwin Park had few restaurants, yet was on a busy route between L.A. and Palm Springs -- a perfect spot for a hamburger stand.The practical Snyders named it In-N-Out to evoke car culture convenience. Harry received $5,000 startup capital from local businessman Charles Noddin and opened the first store in October 1948 on Garvey Avenue, across from the home he shared with Esther.Adding spark to his concept, Harry developed a two-way radio ordering system that let customers get a quick meal without leaving their cars.More than high tech, the high quality of the burgers and fries kept customers coming back.Harry inspected each produce shipment and made sure lettuce was hand-leafed, with tomatoes and onions up to par.Esther formed the day’s patties each morning. At home, she kept a close eye on the books while Harry supervised the stand.Soon, Esther's workload grew with the addition of their two sons, Guy and Rich. Leaving the day-to-day operations to Harry, she continued to do the bookkeeping and always stopped by the store to check in with employees and let them know how important they were to In-N-Out’s burgeoning success.The Snyders' combination of street and book smarts helped create a simple yet exceptional experience. Lines of happy customers around the block became a daily occurrence. After three years, in 1951, In-N-Out opened a second location in nearby Covina.Noddin and Harry soon dissolved the partnership after the former pushed to cut costs by reducing employee pay and using cheaper ingredients. Harry vowed to never again take on outside financing.Harry didn’t dream of putting an In-N-Out on every corner. His goal was to create a sustainable and healthy business to pass on to his sons.He knew a healthy business could be achieved only if his associates felt respected and cared for.From the beginning, Harry and Esther paid associates above minimum wage. Vendors received the same treatment. The Snyders always paid invoices on time.They didn’t cut corners and expected the same treatment from their employees and vendors.If a produce vendor was caught sneaking subpar product into a shipment, Harry ended their relationship on the spot.Employees were so satisfied working at In-N-Out, many didn’t want to leave even though they had plateaued in their positions.Meanwhile, the Snyders continued to expand, in large part to provide professional opportunities to those who helped build the firm.Harry and Esther did so under two conditions: (1) They had to own a building outright. (2) They had to know who would manage it.In-N-Out grew in the 1950s and ’60s with its traditional look and ethos -- perhaps a reassuring presence during huge cultural shifts.“There’s something very appealing about ‘No surprises.’ When you walked in, you knew you were going to be taken care of,” Michael Stern, co-author of “Roadfood,” told IBD.In the mid-1960s, Harry invested in the Irwindale Raceway, a now-defunct drag strip, and had In-N-Out provide event food.After visitors from other parts of the country tasted their first In-N-Out burger at the L.A.-area track, they took glowing reports far and wide. That made the eatery more than a West Coast secret, and requests to franchise grew.In 1976, Harry died at age 63 from lung cancer. In-N-Out had grown to 18 locations in Southern California, and 24-year-old Rich became its new president. The young man was committed to preserving his parents’ commitment to quality, service and cleanliness.With the help of industry mentors and the blessing of Esther, who maintained the position of secretary-treasurer, Rich expanded In-N-Out at a faster clip.In order to grow while maintaining the company’s core values, he came up with two innovations.The first was In-N-Out University, a training facility that opened in 1984. The school taught the management practices that Harry standardized in the early years. Rich “started videotaping employees, and they would review the tapes (during training) to discuss performance, a practice Rich picked up from the NFL,” Perman said.The second was a customer care line, a toll-free phone system staffed by those who had worked at In-N-Out restaurants.During the 1980s, Esther continued her day-to-day involvement in the chain’s operations while increasing philanthropic activities.In 1984, the company began supporting causes to help abused and neglected children, leading to the In-N-Out Burger Foundation.In 1992, In-N-Out opened its first store outside of California — in Las Vegas. But the next year, tragedy struck. Rich died when his plane crashed on the way home from a store opening in Fresno, Calif.Guy, who had worked at In-N-Out but struggled with substance abuse, stepped in as president.By many accounts, Guy demonstrated a talent for updating quality controls. But in 1999, he died from a drug overdose.In-N-Out had grown from those 18 stores when Harry died to a chain of 140 stores in two states.At nearly 80, Esther finally assumed the presidency.She remained the emotional center of the firm, visiting stores and checking on employees regularly.Lynsi Snyder, Guy’s daughter and the only member of the family’s third generation, was only 17 at the time of her father’s death.After high school, she assumed various roles in the company and moved toward the top.After Esther died at age 86, Mark Taylor rose from vice president of operations to the presidency.Then in 2010, Lynsi finally took the helm.The operating procedures instilled by Harry and Esther continue to resonate with customers.In 2015, In-N-Out won Nation’s Restaurant News’ top consumer pick for a limited-service chain for the third year in a row.Meanwhile, Lynsi Snyder-Ellingson is following in her grandparents’ footsteps. The new owner has said she will pass the company to her four children.Built In-N-Out Burger from a hamburger stand to 300-plus location chain.
Overcame: Childhood poverty.
Lesson: Take care of the employees, and they’ll take care of the customers.
“Keep it real simple. Do one thing and do it the best you can,” said Harry Snyder.

Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC parent Yum Brands (YUM) on Thursday said same-store sales in its China segment likely fell 3% in November, an announcement that came ahead of its plans to discuss how spinning off the struggling division by the end of next year would benefit investors.
Few seemed to be all that impressed by the financial outlook and potential investor perks the company announced Thursday in connection with its annual investor conference in Plano, Texas.

S&P on Thursday downgraded Yum's credit rating to junk after the company earlier in the day announced plans to return $6.2 billion of capital to shareholders before the separation of its China business, expected by the end of next year.

S&P said the return to shareholders was "a significant shift from the company's previous financial policy ... and results in our reassessment of the company's financial risk profile as 'highly leveraged,'" according to StreetInsider.
Yum shares closed down 0.8% in the stock market today, paring earlier losses.
The company stuck to its Q4 same-store sales guidance of flat to 4% growth for the China segment.

The forecast comes after the company's China business has suffered after food-safety scandals and a broader economic slowdown in the nation. The company's planned separation into two separate publicly traded ones, announced in October, was intended to firm up the rest of the company's business outside China.

Yum also said the separation of its China business would create two companies aiming for 15% annual shareholder return, as measured by EPS growth and dividend yield. As a single company, Yum has a target of 10% EPS growth or more, the company said.

The company also said it expected "about flat to low-single-digit positive full-year 2015 EPS growth." Analysts expect a 2% gain. In its Q3 earnings release in October, Yum said it expected "full-year EPS growth to be low-single-digit positive" amid currency headwinds and worse-than-expected sluggishness in China.
Operating profit growth for 2016 is seen at 10% next year on a constant currency basis, with its China division also growing by 10%.
The spinoff, Yum China, will list on the NYSE and may also list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, the company said.

Analysts had modeled a slip in sales to $6.2 billion.Globally, comps rose 5%. In the company's high-growth markets, operating income jumped 27%, helped by an easier comparison in China, where the company suffered from a food safety scare in 2014 after a supplier sold expired meat to McDonald's and Yum Brands' (YUM) KFC.McDonald's management said on an earnings call that it's mulling a sale of part of its stake in the company's struggling Japan business and plans to open 250-plus restaurants in China this year. But it was all-day breakfast that dominated the discussion -- and the U.S. comp growth."Our guess is this result implies the chain outperformed the fast-food industry by about three (percentage points)," RBC Capital Markets said in a research note. "While input costs have started to turn favorable for McDonald’s (and projected to be down 1-2% in 2016), we believe that All Day Breakfast was also a contributor to lower cost-of-goods percentages."Company-operated restaurant expenses fell 7% during the quarter. Breakfast items are generally cheaper as they relate to cost of sales, noted Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, and beef costs have dropped as cattle herds expand.He also pointed to other changes that likely contributed to the rebound, such as searing beef patties better, toasting buns just before giving burgers to customers, and making the menu board more efficient."I think there’s been a number of operational improvements that they’ve done that have been mostly behind the scenes," Slabaugh told Investor's Business Daily.McDonald's Q4 success comes after years of struggles for the chain, which had suffered as more diners, seeking fresher, higher-quality fare, flocked to fast-casual outlets like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).But Chipotle has had problems of its own, namely a food-borne illness outbreak last year that has forced the company into damage control. Shares of other fast-casual chains and fast-food rivals have also drifted lower, while McDonald's shares have risen in recent weeks.Chipotle stock closed down 1.9% Monday and has plunged more than 40% since October. Once high-flying Shake Shack (SHAK) has tumbled 59% from its peak.Shares of Yum Brands, Burger King parent Restaurant Brands (QSR), Wendy’s (WEN) and Jack In The Box (JACK) have lost ground too.Piper Jaffray analyst Nicole Miller Regan noted that some rivals in the sector are only now starting to tweak their strategies, while McDonald's is putting its own in place."They spent the last 12-plus months creating strategy, and now they’re executing," she told IBD.

Top U.S. consumer companies like Apple (AAPL) and Starbucks (SBUX) are growing their footprint in China and laying the groundwork for another takeoff, even as the world's No. 2 economy slams industrial giants with the slowest growth in a generation. Starbucks already has nearly 2,000 stores in mainland China and plans to have 3,400 by 2019. CEO Howard Schultz was in…

Starbucks (SBUX) is bullish about capturing more market share in China, even as the country experiences market turbulence. The coffee chain reportedly plans to open 500 stores this year in China, with the goal of operating 3,400 stores there by 2019. There are currently 2,000 Starbucks locations in the country. China is the company's second-largest and most rapidly growing market,…

China's falling yuan means U.S. multinational corporations face more pressure on their profits, but the greenback likely won't appreciate as dramatically as it did last year, analysts say. The People's Bank of China on Wednesday guided the yuan to the lowest official level it has seen in five years, sending it to all-time weak levels in offshore markets. It's the…

Here's a quick rundown of Monday's after-hours headlines: Nike (NKE) signed NBA star LeBron James to a lifetime deal. The terms were undisclosed. James has been working with Nike since 2003. In September, Stephen Curry extended his contract with Nike rival Under Armour (UA) until 2024. Yum Brands (YUM), the operator of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, said that…

Echoing Starbucks' (SBUX) foray into mobile ordering, Dunkin' Brands' (DNKN) Dunkin' Donuts said it is testing its own mobile order service in Portland, Maine, available to users of its loyalty program.

The doughnut-and-coffee chain said DD Perks Rewards Program members can use its On-the-Go Ordering app to place orders in advance and pick them up in store or at the drive-thru. Orders can be made up to 24 hours in advance.
Dunkin' Brands has likely been watching the success of Starbucks' Mobile-Order-and-Pay service, which is bundled into the java giant's mobile app.

As of October, mobile payments make up 21% of all Starbucks transactions in the U.S., said CEO Howard Schultz during the company's last earnings call, noting a "pattern of accelerated adoption" of mobile ordering as the feature was rolled out nationwide, then in the U.K. and Canada.

Starbucks has over 20 million loyalty program members, more than five times as many Dunkin' Donuts Perks members. Dunkin' management said in late October that it has more then 3.6 million rewards members, and nearly 50 million app downloads.
Separately, Dunkin' Donuts introduced Wednesday a DoorDash-enabled delivery pilot in Dallas, Texas, with plans to make its Dunkin' Delivery service available in Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles and D.C.
Yum Brands (YUM)-owned KFC announced last week that it was teaming with DoorDash on deliveries in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Dunkin' shares closed up 0.3% Wednesday in the stock market today. Starbucks shares advanced 2.1%. Yum Brands rose 1.7%.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Microsoft (MSFT) received a pair of price target cuts Friday following a disappointing quarterly report, while Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) also had its price target lowered and Starbucks (SBUX) got a higher price target.BMO Capital Markets lowered its price target on Microsoft to 57 from 58 and Morgan Stanley lowered it to 64 from 66. Late Thursday, the Redmond, Wash.-based tech giant fell short of fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings views and also offered disappointing sales guidance.Microsoft shares closed down 7.2% on the stock market today.Alphabet’s stock price retreated 5.4% following a disappointing quarter of its own. On Thursday, the company missed Wall Street expectations on the top and bottom lines.Alphabet’s price target was cut to 888 from 930 at Stifel, to 850 from 900 at Morgan Stanley, and to 825 from 910 at Needham.Starbucks’ price target was raised to 72 from 69 by Goldman Sachs, which maintained its buy rating on the stock.Even so, the coffee king’s stock price fell 4.9% Friday following the previous day’s disappointing fiscal Q2 report, which included a revenue miss and a weak full-year forecast.Shares of Under Armour (UA) edged up 0.1% after its price target was raised to 53 from 50 by Telsey Advisory Group. The performance apparel company beat quarterly earnings views Thursday.General Motors (GM) fell 1.5% after its price target was raised to 34 from 30 at RBC Capital Markets, which rates the stock a sector perform.On Thursday, the car maker beat Q1 earnings estimates, driven by strong results in the U.S and China and an improved performance in Europe.Taco Bell parent Yum Brands (YUM) had its price target hiked to 94 from 90 at RBC Capital Markets, which maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Shares fell 0.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Cola-Cola (KO) got a new price target Thursday following a mixed quarterly report, while American Express (AXP) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) saw their price targets hiked.Citigroup maintained its buy rating on Coca-Cola and gave the iconic soft drink maker a price target of 50, which is in line with recent price target changes to the stock.On Wednesday, Coca-Cola reported first-quarter sales and earnings that fell less than feared, but sluggish shipments of soda and other products turned Wall Street off.Coca-Cola closed down 1.6% in the stock market today after tumbling 4.8% to 44.37 on Wednesday. Coca-Cola has now undercut its March breakout from a 44.01 entry point.American Express shares rose 0.9% on a pair of price target hikes, after the credit card company beat Q1 earnings and revenue estimates late Wednesday.Morgan Stanley raised its price target on the stock to 68 from 64 and maintained its equal-weight rating. Keefe Bruyette & Woods, which rates the stock a market perform, raised its price target to 74 from 67.Palo Alto Networks’ price target was hiked to 185 from 171 at Morgan Stanley, which maintained its overweight rating on the stock.Palo Alto rose 4.4%, retaking its 50-day line.Credit Suisse assumed coverage on software firm Adobe Systems (ADBE) with a neutral rating and 105 price target. Adobe ended essentially flat.IBD's Take: Is Adobe Systems a buy, hold or sell right now? Take a Free trial of IBD Leaderboard to find out.Dish Network (DISH) got a couple of new price targets following Wednesday’s better-than-expected earnings report. FBR Capital raised its price target on the stock to 46 from 45, while Telsey Advisory Group lowered it to 69 from 74.Dish rose 1.4%, helped by a new deal with Viacom (VIAB). Viacom stock shot up 14%.Yum Brands (YUM) had its price target raised to 85 from 81 by JPMorgan, which has an overweight rating on the stock. Late Wednesday, the Taco Bell and KFC parent beat Q1 earnings views ahead of the spinoff of its China business.Shares of Yum fell 1% Thursday after initially trading higher.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Apple (AAPL) pushed backed its quarterly earnings report by one day, to Tuesday, April 26, after the market close. Apple was little changed after hours following a 0.2% regular session gain.United Airlines (UAL) said it would temper its growth plans to balance out supply with demand, following similar remarks from Delta Air Lines (DAL) last week, and said it expects second-quarter consolidated passenger unit revenue to fall at least 6.5%.United Airlines' first quarter earnings per share fell 19% to $1.23, beating views by a nickel. Revenue fell 4.8% to $8.2 billion, in line with estimates. Consolidated passenger unit revenue fell 7.4%, with the strong dollar weighing and declines in holiday close-in business travel that were bigger than expected.The results come as pressure grows on airlines to turn around declines in unit revenue, a key measure of a carrier's performance.Earlier, United announced a board shakeup to appease activist investors.United stock fell 2.3% in late trading.Yum Brands (YUM), the operator of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut, said it was on pace to spin off its China unit by the end of the year after a series of food-safety scandals.The company reported Q1 EPS up 19% to 95 cents, surpassing forecasts by 12 cents. Sales of $2.62 bil narrowly missed, flat vs. a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 2%, which China comps up 6%. Yum also boosted full-year core operating profit guidance.Shares rose 4% breaking out a long base after trying to do so during the regular session, up 0.5%.Qualcomm (QCOM) shares fell 3% after the chipmaker forecast third-quarter earnings per share of $99 cents to $1.00, below estimates for $1.02. Qualcomm sees sales of $5.2 billion to $6 billion, with the midpoint just topping views for $5.56 billion.As for the fiscal second quarter, sales fell 19% to $5.6 billion, but that was better than expectations for $5.34 billion. EPS slid 26% to 1.04, also topping an analyst outlook for 96 cents.Citrix Software (CTXS), cloud management software maker, said Q1 EPS jumped 81% to $1.18 on revenue up 8.5% to $826 mil, both topping. Citrix stock rose 7.8%.F5 Networks (FFIV) Q2 revenue rose 2% to $483.7 mil, missing, with EPS up 5% to $1.68, beating. Q3 EPS guidance of $1.77- $1.80 topped; its sales view missed. Shares rose 4.5%.Lam Research (LRCX) said Q3 revenue fell 5% to $1.314 bil, in line. Lam's EPS of $1.18 topped views. The chip equipment maker’s stock edged higher.Tractor Supply (TSCO), which sells supplies to farms and ranches reported a 19% bump in Q1 EPS to 50 cents, with sales up 10% to $1.47 billion, both beating views. Tractor Supply stock rose nearly 5% late, breaking out of a base.Casino operator Las Vegas Sands' (LVS) Q1 EPS fell 32% to 45 cents, badly missing estimates for 63 cents. Sales slid 10% to $2.72 billion, short of views for $2.88 billion. Las Vegas Sands fell 5% late. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) also fell after hours.

The Nashville Distribution House, located in Mount Juliet, Tenn., is Under Armour's third domestic distribution facility. The sportswear maker and Nike (NKE) rival said that with the…

With the U.S. economy faring relatively well and the Federal Reserve signaling its first interest rate hike in nearly a decade, the dollar is on the march. Yum Brands' decision Tuesday to split off its China business and separate into two publicly traded companies means that the remaining non-China unit will be "significantly de-risked," according to an analyst.In contrast to its early success in the giant consumer market, Yum's (YUM) now-embattled China unit has been hit by economic volatility in the country, continuing fallout from food-safety scandals, and other missteps."We view today's announcement as a large positive, as it will get Yum Brands off of the China roller coaster in a meaningful way and allow for better focus on enhancing non-China business lines (although more could and should be done)," wrote Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski, who reiterated a buy rating on the stock.Shares of Yum closed up 1.8%.The spinoff comes despite the fact that China accounted for over half of Yum's total revenue in fiscal 2014 and was a major growth driver for years as Yum was quick to capitalize on the burgeoning fast-food cravings of China's rising middle class.But Yum's Q3 report earlier this month offered no signs of a turnaround in China, where same-store sales growth of 2% fell far below views for a 9.6% jump. The company, which also missed Q3 earnings and revenue expectations, said China sales remain "difficult to forecast" as the segment's recovery is slower than expected.Yum now sees "flat to low-single-digit" full-year EPS growth, down from guidance in the low single digits, which was lowered from an earlier view for "at least 10%" growth.By the end of 2016, Yum expects its China split to be complete. Shanghai-based Yum China will become a franchisee of Yum Brands in mainland China and have exclusive rights to KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell.'Pure Play' FranchisorThe spinoff is expected to have "no significant debt, with substantial financial capacity to invest in its business," said the company in a statement.Yum China is on track for 700 new restaurant openings this year and is "targeting expansion to over 20,000 restaurants in China" down the road.Meanwhile, the core Yum Brands will become "more of a 'pure play' franchisor over time" and continue with the global expansion of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell. The company said it is aiming for at least 95% of its 41,000 locations to be franchisee-owned and operated by the end of 2017, following the split.The company said last week that it was wrapping up its strategic review.
Amazon's (AMZN) price target was raised Tuesday and the online marketplace said it had record sales for its Fire devices over the weekend. Yum Brands (YUM) was upgraded on its China business spinoff.

Barclays raised Amazon's price target raised to 850 from 700 and kept its overweight rating on the stock. Amazon also said Tuesday its Fire devices were the best-selling products during its Black Friday sale. It plans to speed up production to build "millions more" of its Fire tablets.
Amazon shares closed up 2.2% to 679.06 in the stock market today.

Yum Brands, the operator of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC restaurants, was upgraded to outperform from market perform by Cowen. The analysts are bullish on the company's spinoff of its China business following food safety issues the past few years that have hit the stock.
Shares of Yum climbed 2.7%.

Web hosting and cloud computing service provider Rackspace Hosting (RAX) was upgraded to outperform from sector perform by RBC Capital Markets. The analysts have a 36 price target on the stock. Rackspace shares closed up 2.1%.

Barclays upgraded pharmaceutical and medical companies Merck (MRK), Eli Lilly (LLY) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) to overweight. Merck shares jumped 2.9%. Eli Lilly shares climbed 5.4% and J&J shares edged up 1.1%.

Stock futures traded lower, but were paring losses on the approach to Tuesday's starting bell. Dow futures showed a 36.5-point loss. Nasdaq 100 futures were down a scant 2.5 points. S&P 500 futures were 2.5 points in the red. Small caps were modestly lower, with Russell 2000 futures off 1.3 points.

The stock market today felt a mixed effect from housing data, which showed housing starts jumping to an annualized rate of 1.206 million in September. The first gain in three months, the number was a nice uptick from August's pace of 1.126 million and above consensus estimates of 1.147 million starts.
Building permits, which signal future activity, slowed to 1.103 million, down from 1.170 in August. A slowdown isn't unusual this time of year, but the number was below expectations for no change.

In stocks, hospital staffing firm Team Health (TMH) vaulted 24% in premarket action. The Wall Street Journal reported Nashville, Tenn.-based AmSurg (AMSG) proposed earlier this month a cash stock deal valuing Team Health at 71.47, or around $5 billion. Team Health, which agreed in August to acquire IPC Healthcare for $1.6 billion, reportedly declined the offer. AmSurg shares slipped a fraction.

SanDisk (SNDK) surged 8% after reports that it was in late-stage talks to merge with hard-drive maker Western Digital (WDC). Bloomberg cited unnamed sources saying that Western was talking about a bid between 80 and 90 per share, and said the deal could close this week.
SanDisk is scheduled to report Q3 results after Wednesday's close. SanDisk shares ended Monday 63% above an August low and in a 15-month consolidation. Western Digital shares were unchanged.

Yum Brands (YUM) rolled up a 6% gain following the announcement that it would spin off as a separate company for operations in China. The owner of the KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut chains counts 6,900 restaurants in China, which generated $6.9 billion in revenue last year. The business could grow to 20,000 units, the company says, but it has struggled with a slow comeback following a raft of food-quality issues last year. Yum Brands revenue outside China was $6.3 billion. The stock has been correcting since May.
Some heavyweight earnings reports landed ahead of the open, with Verizon (VZ) up 1% and Lockheed Martin (LMT) down 1% after delivering results.

IBM (IBM) slumped 5% after a 9% EPS decline beat, and a 14% slip in revenue missed consensus projections. Management said in the report late Monday that currency issues trimmed $1.9 billion from revenue, and lowered its full-year EPS guidance . IBM shares have been slipping for 33 months.

Harley-Davidson (HOG) laid down a 7% loss and lowered its full-year shipment projection after the company reported flat earnings and a fractional revenue gain in the third quarter. The company cited increased competition. The stock has been plowing through a correction for 17 months.

In overseas markets, China lodged a mixed session, with the Shanghai Composite up 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index down 0.4%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ticked up 0.4%. Europe's major indexes carted narrow losses into midday trade.

The dollar was modestly mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen. Bonds inched a shade higher. IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, which ranked No. 5 at the start of 2015, now ranks 111 out of the 197 industries IBD tracks and has fallen 18% since hitting a collective…

Stocks wobbled in and out of mixed territory Wednesday morning, as earnings news, a rising dollar and a pullback in oil prices combined to pressure equities.The Nasdaq managed a 0.1% gain and the Dow held just below the 0.1% mark. The S&P 500 struggled against narrow losses.The stock market today moved in quiet volume. Trade slowed 4% on the NYSE and was down 8% on the Nasdaq, vs. action at the same time Tuesday.Homebuilder stocks traded lower, despite a better-than-expected reading on existing-home sales for March. The National Association of Realtors reported sales rose to an annualized rate of 5.33 million, up from 5.07 million in February and above projections for a sales pace of 5.268 million.The Dow felt the pull of undertow from Boeing (BA) and Coca-Cola (KO). Boeing thumped out a 3% loss after Bank of America downgraded the stock to neutral from underperform. Coke shed nearly 4% after its Q1 earnings, and revenue fell slightly less than consensus forecasts, but weakness in international markets left volume flat.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and American Express (AXP) led the index, up a bit more than 1% each.Check Point Software (CHKP) dropped 4% in heavy trade after earnings sneaked past consensus expectations, revenue just met views and management gave Q2 earnings guidance near the low end of the consensus range. The stock pared losses after finding support at its 50-day moving average. The dive cut 6% below an 88.08 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Discover Financial (DFS) and St. Jude Medical (STJ) led the S&P 500, surging 7% and 4%, respectively, after healthy Q1 reports. Discover's powerful volume gain lifted it well up the right side of a five-month cup base, easily clearing its 200-day moving average and putting shares within 3% of a 58.18 buy point.St. Jude is up 25% from a mid-February low, but still below its 200-day line and deep in a nine-month consolidation.MaxLinear (MXL) topped the IBD 50 list by a wide margin, surging 7% after revising its Q1 revenue and gross profit outlook. The stock tripped a sell rule Tuesday, dropping more than 8% below a 17.85 buy point and cutting its 50-day moving average in heavy trade. Wednesday's gain brought shares back even with the 50-day line.A big after-hours session today is scheduled to include quarter reports from American Express, Qualcomm (QCOM), United Continental (UAL) and Yum Brands (YUM).

President Obama in 2011 endorsed a U.S. pivot to Asia, working to strengthen alliances in the region as China rises. Now McDonald's (MCD) is making its own strategic shift, announcing plans Thursday to add more than 1,500 locations in China, Hong Kong and South Korea over the next five years.The fast food giant already owns more than 2,800 restaurants in those markets, mostly company owned. But this time McDonald's said it's seeking "strategic partners who will add value and unlock growth potential in key markets" to help in its Asia expansion."This will allow McDonald's to accelerate our growth and scale faster across diverse markets placing us closer to our customers and the communities we serve," CEO Steve Easterbrook said in a statement. We're in the midst of transforming our business and taking a strategic and thoughtful approach to enhance our ability to grow around the world. These actions build on our turnaround efforts and will advance local ownership, enable faster decision-making and achieve restaurant growth."McDonald's recently said it was seeking strategic allies in Japan and Taiwan. McDonald's has a goal of boosting franchise locations to 95%, even in the U.S. where the franchise model is under attack.In China alone, McDonald's will boost its store count to 3,500 from 2,200 now, Easterbrook told the Wall Street Journal. That would make China its No. 2 market after the U.S. and ahead of Japan.McDonald’s has over 14,000 locations in the U.S. and more than 36,000 worldwide.McDonald's Asia expansion comes as Yum Brands (YUM) seeks to spin off its China operations. Yum's KFC and Pizza Hut chains have a big foothold in China, with Taco Bell set to open its first location in the country this year. China used to be a huge growth driver for Yum, but food illness scares slammed sales, which have been slow to recover.McDonald's has seen its U.S. business improve, helped by an all-day breakfast menu and other changes. Thursday's announcement suggests the company is now turning its attention to overseas initiatives as well.McDonald's shares rose as high as 126.96 on the stock market today, a new record, but pulled back to close up 3 cents at 12.86. On Wednesday, shares moved out of a cup base with a buy point of 124.93.Sonic Corp. (SONC), a burgers-and-shakes chain, rose 1.7% to 35.16, extending its breakout. On Wednesday, shares soared  6.2% to 34.58, clearing a consolidation to a 1-year high. Sonic reported strong earnings late Tuesday.Yum Brands fell 0.5% at 81.85.

China's official manufacturing index fell to a 3-year low in November. But the services PMI rose, highlighting an economic shift helping Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE) and Starbucks (SBUX). The manufacturing activity gauge fell 0.2 point to 49.6, the worst since August 2012, according to the National Bureau of Statistics on Tuesday local time. The reading was slightly below views and…

The "Fight For $15" minimum-wage campaign demand might seem clear as day, but there's more than meets the eye — over $3 an hour more. Once all the nonwage costs, including payroll taxes, paid sick leave and the big one — ObamaCare's employer mandate — are added to the $15 base wage, minimum compensation for a full-time worker could rise…

McDonald's (MCD) held its annual investor/analyst day Tuesday on the same day that thousands of fast-food workers nationwide held protests calling for higher pay, but the company chose to focus on its growth strategies.The meeting took place as McDonald's eyes ways to better compete against fast-food rivals such as Yum Brands (YUM) — owner of the KFC and Taco Bell chains — as well as fast-casual chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Shake Shack (SHAK).During the first hour of the scheduled four-hour meeting, McDonald's Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook and other officials outlined several new goals that the company looks to achieve in coming months."My priorities for McDonald's as a modern, progressive burger company are threefold: driving operational growth, creating brand excitement and enhancing financial value," Easterbrook said. "We are taking bold, urgent action to reset the business and prepare the company for the next chapter of its history."McDonald's constant-currency financial targets for 2016 include systemwide sales growth of 3% to 5% and operating income growth of 5% to 7%, excluding potential charges associated with its refranchising strategy and cost-saving initiatives.More Franchises, Fewer CostsIn terms of refranchising, the company raised its target to 4,000 restaurants from an earlier target of 3,500. This accelerates the pace and increases the global franchised percentage from the current 81% to about 93% by the end of 2018. McDonald's long-term goal is to become 95% franchised.McDonald's also raised its net annual general and administration cost-savings target to $500 million, most of which will be realized by the end of 2017. This reflects a $200 million increase from the previously announced target. The new target excludes the impact of foreign currency changes.In addition, Easterbrook said McDonald's has no plans to spin off its properties into real estate investment trusts, as had been speculated."We have given REITs serious consideration, but we don't believe it serves best the interests of shareholders to pursue REITS at this time," he said.Easterbrook also mentioned plans to grow its store count internationally and improve McDonald's level of efficiency and customer service. It looks to add more restaurants along Germany's Autobahn, for example. Meanwhile, it is looking to change the way it toasts buns and grills meat."We were not executing to our standards," he said. "We were missing customer expectations in too many places. For too long we've asked customers to adapt to us. A big part of turning that around is giving customers more choice and always adapting to meet their needs."Meanwhile, McDonald's board declared a quarterly cash dividend of 89 cents per share of common stock, payable on Dec. 15 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Dec. 1. This represents a 5% increase over its previous quarterly dividend.Protests NationwideWhile the meeting was taking place, fast-food workers in hundreds of U.S. cities held strikes and demonstrations calling for higher wages. It was the largest collection of rallies yet in a cause that seeks to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.The demonstrations began around dawn at McDonald's locations in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. The protests are expected to continue throughout the U.S. for the remainder of the day and culminate in a rally at the Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee.Earlier this year McDonald's said it would raise wages by more than 10% for workers at U.S. restaurants that it operates, and pay at least $1 more per hour than the local minimum wage for workers at U.S. restaurants.Financially, though, the company has been in a bit of a funk of late. It has logged five straight quarters of lower sales. Year-over-year earnings have declined in four of the last five quarters, though its most recent quarter showed a 28% EPS gain. That kind of performance compares unfavorably to other stocks in IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, including Starbucks (SBUX), Chipotle and Shake Shack.Even so, McDonald's stock price has been on a nice roll lately. Shares hit a fresh high of 113.96 on Oct. 26 and are up more than 10% since Oct. 21.Growth DriversIn a Monday morning note, RBC analyst David Palmer said McDonald's stock price has mainly been driven by gains in return on invested capital as well as recent earnings growth and earnings-per-share revisions.EPS growth has been driven in part by same-store sales gains in international markets, he said.On the downside, U.S. comps "(have) dramatically slowed," Palmer noted. "The company's struggles inside the U.S. have been the most troubling since declining same-store sales have been the result of significant share losses in an otherwise healthy U.S. fast food market in 2015."On a more positive note, McDonald's recent decision to offer an all-day breakfast menu has been a success."We believe that McDonald's consumer base is broader at breakfast, so increased availability of breakfast items could inspire trial of other core items and day parts," Palmer said.McDonald's shares rose 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks added 1.4%, while Chipotle climbed 3.2% and Yum lost 0.3%.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Stocks finished mostly lower Tuesday as weakness in biotechs and other medical stocks weighed on the Nasdaq. The Nasdaq finished down 0.7%; the S&P gave up 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.1% in the stock market today. Volume was lower on the NYSE and 3% higher than Monday on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.The Dow was held aloft by an 8% gain in DuPont (DD). Late Monday, the company announced CEO Ellen Kullman would retire, fueling speculation the company would be broken up.After the close, Adobe Systems (ADPE) was trading sharply lower. The company forecast fiscal 2016 revenue of $5.7 billion and non-GAAP earnings of $2.70. Both numbers were well below Wall Street estimates.Also after hours, Yum Brands (YUM) served up an unpleasant quarterly report, missing on earnings and revenue and lowering guidance. The company cited a slower-than-expected recovery in China and currency issues.Before the open Wednesday, the Mortgage Bankers Association reports the mortgage index for the week ended Oct. 3. At 10:30 a.m., the Energy Information Administration reports crude oil inventories for the week ended Oct. 3.Also before the open, Acuity Brands (AYI), Constellation Brands (STZ) and Global Payments (GPN) issue quarterly reports.Acuity is expected to report $1.64 a share, a 30% increase from a year ago. Constellation is expected to report EPS of $1.32 a share, a 19% increase from a year earlier. Global Payments is forecast to report $1.43, a 17% increase.

Yahoo (YHOO) shares finished lower Wednesday on several price target cuts that followed a weak earnings report, while Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) also had its price target cut, Twitter (TWTR) was downgraded, and VMware (VMW) was hit with a series of downgrades.Yahoo was downgraded to neutral from buy at Mizuho Securities, which also lowered its price target on the stock to 37 from 40. In addition, Axiom Capital lowered its price target on Yahoo to 44 from 45, and RBC Capital Markets cut it to 42 from 47.Late Tuesday, Yahoo missed Q3 earnings and revenue viewsand offered disappointing Q4 revenue guidance. On the upside, it also said it's on track to complete the proposed tax-free spinoff of its 15% stake in China e-commerce leader Alibaba (BABA), and that it reached a three-year agreement with Google, the main unit of Alphabet (GOOGL), to team up in Internet search and advertising.Even so, Yahoo shares closed down 5.2% on the stock market today. Alibaba lost 3.2%, while Alphabet gave up 1.2% a day before its earnings report.Twitter was downgraded to underweight by Morgan Stanley and given a 24 price target — well below other recent price targets on the stock. Twitter shares ended down 5.2%.Chipotle sank 5.7% after Wedbush slashed its price target to 740 from 800 following Tuesday's quarterly profit miss. Although sales rose 12% to $12.2 billion, it was the fourth straight quarter of decelerating growth on the top line.VMware received several downgrades, a day after it beat quarterly EPS and revenue views but offered disappointing Q4 revenue guidance. Maxim Group downgraded the stock to hold from buy and cut its price target to 75 from 100.Monness Crespi & Hardt downgraded VMware to neutral from buy, while Pacific Crest downgraded it to sector weight from overweight. Several other analysts also downgraded the stock.The virtualization-software maker's majority owner, EMC (EMC), is being acquired by Dell in a $67 billion deal. Although many investors wanted EMC to spin off VMware, Dell will retain control. VMWare shares tumbled 19.4%, while EMC lost 6.3%.Verizon Communications (VZ) fell 0.8% after its price target was cut to 53 from 59 at Argus, which maintained its buy rating on the stock.Medical software firm Cerner (CERN) was initiated at market outperform with an 82 price target by Avondale Partners. Its shares finished essentially unchanged.Stifel cut Harley-Davidson's (HOG) price target to 59 from 71 but maintained its buy rating on the stock. Harley shares fell 2.5% after diving 13.9% on Tuesday following weak results.Deep discount retailer Dollar General (DG) rose 0.8% after it was upgraded to neutral by Bank of America. Dollar General's stock price is off about 17% from its high of 81.42 set in July.Yum Brands (YUM) climbed 0.7% after its price target was raised to 87 from 80 by RBC Capital Markets. The owner of the KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut chains said Tuesday it plans to spin off its China operations.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Single-tenant retail locations are hot investment properties these days . That's especially true for restaurants, where sales have grown well above the national retail average, according to a recent report from Marcus & Millichap. Enter Store Capital (STOR), one of the most active real estate investment trusts (REITs) involved in buying free-standing single-tenant locations — especially restaurants. It buys stores…

Yum Brands (YUM) is under growing pressure to spin off its China operations, which provided over half of Yum's revenue and operating profit in Q3, just as Yahoo (YHOO) is moving ahead with plans to spin off its Alibaba (BABA) stake despite uncertain tax consequences. Credit Suisse analyst Jason West raised his rating on Yum to neutral from underperform Thursday…

Shares of Domino's Pizza (DPZ) moved lower Thursday after the pizza-delivery chain fell short of quarterly earnings views, dragged down by high insurance expenses and unfavorable currency-exchange rates. Domino's results came a day after Yum Brands (YUM), owner of the Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell chains, sank nearly 19% following a miss on quarterly earnings and revenue estimates. Reporting…

Tesla Motors (TSLA) got a price target raise despite missing Q1 delivery figures. Analysts were dived on Palo Alto Networks (PANW)  Tuesday while Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) were downgraded. Starbucks (SBUX) nabbed a buy as coverage was started on a plateful of restaurants by Evercore ISI Group.Credit Suisse took Tesla's PT to 280 from 240 while keeping an outperform on the luxury car maker as preorders soar for its $35,000 Model 3, even though Q1 deliveries fell short of estimates.Tesla shares down 2% in the morning, closed up 3.4% to 255.47.Meanwhile, Bank of America downgraded Cisco to neutral. Needham upped its PT on cybersecurity firm Palo Alto Networks to 187 from 171, a day after Palo Alto's analyst day. But Goldman Sachs trimmed Palo Alto's PT to 188 from 191. Cisco lost 2%, and Palo Alto fell 6% to 151.92.Ruckus Wireless got five downgrades from analysts early Tuesday following Brocade Communications Systems' (BRCD) announcement on Monday that it agreed to buy the wireless firm for $1.2 billion. Brocade shares were up 4.2% Tuesday after sinking 13.6% Monday. Ruckus was up 1.7%, adding to its 32% spike Monday.Needham and Stifel Nicolaus cut their ratings on Ruckus from buy to hold while RBC Capital's went from outperform to sector perform. Macquarie cut its rating to neutral and William Blair's dropped to market perform.Evercore ISI Group started coverage on a bevy of restaurants, but only two with buy ratings: Starbucks and Wendy's (WEN).Starbucks shares were down 0.35%, while Wendy's edged up 1%.It put a hold on Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM), Domino's Pizza (DPZ), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Jack in the Box (JACK) and a sell on Dunkin Brands (DNKN).

San Francisco might manage a $15 minimum wage without much of a dampening effect on employment, but what about a $36-an-hour minimum?That's roughly the equivalent of the challenge now facing El Centro in California's Imperial County, where the $15 minimum wage will equal 95% of the average wage in 2015.It's only logical to expect that El Centro, whose nearly 19% jobless rate in February was the highest of any metropolitan area in the U.S, will have an enormously more difficult time adapting to a $15 wage than San Francisco and San Jose, where average wages are close to $40 and joblessness is just 3% to 4%.Yet California, almost unbelievably, has ignored the dramatic economic disparities from the Bay Area to the Central Valley to the communities near the Mexico border and has embraced a one-size-fits-all $15 wage, phased in by 2022. It puts the Golden State out a limb where neither New York nor Oregon dared to go as those liberal states pushed their minimum wages into uncharted territory.Oregon took a three-tiered approach, putting its minimum wage on a path to $14.75 in the Portland metropolitan area by 2022, while the wage will top out at $13.50 in midsize counties and $12.50 in so-called "frontier" areas.New York City will get a $15 minimum wage by 2018, with the surrounding counties getting there by 2022. But the minimum wage for the rest of the state is on course to get to $12.50 an hour by 2021 — with one exception. Quick-service chain restaurants throughout New York will be on the hook for a $15 wage, including small businesses operating a single franchised location. New York's fast-food wage applies to a broad range of limited-service or takeout places, including Subway, Starbucks (SBUX), Wendy’s (WEN), Shake Shack (SHAK), Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell, Dunkin’ Brands’ (DNKN) Dunkin' Donuts and Jamba’s (JMBA) Jamba Juice.On the same day that Gov. Jerry Brown signed the minimum wage law, Dunkin’ announced plans to open 29 franchised stores in the next few years. Such deals don’t come together overnight, and the adoption of a $15 statewide minimum was seemingly sudden and abrupt. Still, the possibility of a $15 wage initiative on the fall ballot has been in the news, so some businesses still see opportunity amid much higher wages.Yet the biggest batch of new Dunkin’ Donuts is slated for Contra Costa County, a suburban county in the East Bay area of the broad San Francisco metropolitan statistical area. With above-average wages and a 4.5% jobless rate, the economy of Contra Costa County will have a far better chance to sustain a $15 minimum wage than Imperial County, an agricultural area bordering Arizona and Mexico.Rather than a great leveler, a $15 minimum wage may end up widening geographical disparities as the high wage scares employers from adding jobs in economically depressed areas.Dunkin’ Brands CEO Nigel Travis told CNN last year that New York's $15 fast-food wage would mean "probably less hiring, probably less growth."In its third-quarter conference call, the company told analysts that one franchise that raised prices in response to a minimum-wage hike lost sales, so it’s advising that the best approach is to focus on increasing sales, not prices.An early warning of the potential downside of adopting a much higher minimum wage came from Wal-Mart (WMT), which earlier this year announced store closures in Los Angeles County and the city of Oakland while scrapping plans for two stores in a low-income part of D.C.The New York Farm Bureau warned that a statewide $15 minimum wage would threaten the financial viability of close to 20% of farms. Particularly if farmers in neighboring states didn’t face a similar hike, the high wage would shrink the size of the state’s agricultural industry and cause farming operations to shift to less labor-intensive crops.Now California has gone where New York feared to go -- at least in most of the state -- and the agriculture industry is bracing for the fallout. One supplier of farm labor predicts a 10% drop in agricultural hiring.The consequences of a $15 wage also may be understated for another reason: When you add up all the nonwage costs -- paid sick leave, extra payroll taxes and the ObamaCare employer mandate to offer health insurance -- California's statewide $15 minimum will really amount to $18.52 for full-time workers.

Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell is delving deeper into the fast-food wars with a nationwide Thursday rollout of its new 10-item $1 Morning Value Menu, which offers a mini skillet bowl, breakfast soft taco and sausage flatbread quesadilla, among other dishes.The company is likely looking at the proliferation of low-price offerings from competitors like Wendy's (WEN) and Restaurant Brands International's (QSR) Burger King, as well as the success that McDonald's (MCD) has had in recent months since introducing all-day breakfast offerings.An NPD study from December found that the all-day breakfast menu was helping McDonald's attract new customers and boost lunch visits, and so far, quarterly results have been backing the change in strategy.The Golden Arches' U.S. same-restaurant sales popped 5.7% in the fourth quarter, reported in late January, far above analyst estimates. It also marked the second straight rise in comps following two years of same-restaurants sales declines.McDonald's shares have risen about 17% since the close of Oct. 6, the day all-day breakfast was launched nationwide, and are now building a flat base with a 124.93 buy point.Meanwhile, Yum shares have largely been in a broad area of consolidation since last May. The stock has declined about 8% since Oct. 6.On Thursday, Yum closed up 0.6%, and McDonald's rose 0.3%.Yum Brands, which also owns KFC and Pizza Hut, is working on a spin-off of its ailing China division.Taco Bell first introduced breakfast two years ago and experimented with items such as waffle tacos before landing on this value-emphasized menu.Competition for even a dollar is fierce. Rival Wendy's offers a "4 for $4" deal. Burger King has a "5 for $4" promotion. McDonald's, in addition to all-day breakfast, serves up two items for $5."While dollar menus disappear across America, Taco Bell is continuing to reinvent breakfast with delicious and unique menu items only Taco Bell can provide, with 10 items for $1 each," Taco Bell's Chief Marketing Officer Marisa Thalberg said in a statement.RELATED:McDonald’s Morning In America: Breakfast Revives U.S. SalesMcDonald’s All-Day Breakfast Draws Amid Chipotle WoesYum Brands Makes Case For Split As China Sales LagImage provided by Shutterstock.
As cybercrime strikes with worrisome frequency, Visa (V) is deploying new technology and services to keep digital thieves at bay and secure its position as the world's largest money card processor.

The late-2013 data security breach at Target (TGT) was a game changer for American merchants, exposing 40 million debit and credit card accounts, costing the big-box retailer tens of millions of dollars and the CEO his job. It accelerated the move to chip-embedded cards in the U.S., which had lagged behind foreign money-card innovation.
Target wasn't the only big victim. Home Depot (HD), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Michaels (MIK), Berkshire Hathaway's (BRKB) Dairy Queen and others also have been badly compromised in the last two years.

Fighting cybercrime has become an endless war as hackers grow more sophisticated, but Wednesday is the last day of blame-sharing. Beginning Thursday, Oct. 1, more liability for money card fraud shifts to merchants and retailers if they don't use the tech to handle the new chip cards from Visa or its rivals.

"The U.S. was the last major global economy that hadn't moved to chip and PIN," said Andrew Jeffrey, an analyst at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. "That made us the weak link in the chain from a security perspective."

Banks reportedly had issued more than 142 million new Visa chip cards in the U.S. by Sept. 1, but still have a way to go. It had 2.2 billion money cards issued globally in 2013, including 702 million in the U.S.
Easing Out The 16 Digits

That's a major change for certain, but a bigger one may be afoot. The 16-digit account number, once as much of a staple of credit cards as landlines were for telephones, is being phased out for online and mobile payments by the big payment card companies.

Visa is among the companies that have begun using "tokens," which substitute the 16-digit number with a randomly generated sequence of alphanumeric characters for each transaction. They make it more difficult for cybercrooks to steal identities.

Moving American consumers from point-of-sale cash transactions to higher-tech digital sales, Visa is clearing the path. The Foster City, Calif.-based company has inked deals with Apple (AAPL), Samsung and Google (GOOGL) to deploy the tokenization tech.

It's the wave of the present. Its rival MasterCard (MA) recently unveiled its own tokenization system for use in so-called digital wallets. Smaller competitors American Express (AXP) and Discover Financial Services (DFS) also have joined the tokenization transition.
Pushing Visa further into the digital world is CEO Charles Scharf, a former JPMorgan executive who took over Visa in 2012.
Chip-and-PIN cards, tokenization and opening up Visa's network beyond bread-and-butter partnerships with banks are shaping up as hallmarks of Scharf's tenure.

One recent product push to digital is Checkout, an online payment service that integrates Visa plastic cards on the Internet via merchants' websites and mobile shopping apps. Yum Brands (YUM) restaurants and Under Armour (UA) are among the 250,000 merchants offering this service. Visa also is extending the service to China, Australia, the United Arab Emirates, Canada and Colombia. It says Checkout has 6 million registered users with average monthly enrollment growing more than 30% in June and July.
Benefits In The Middle
The company is so ubiquitous, Visa seems to be at the center of almost every transaction short of real estate.

"The beauty of Visa's business is they get a very small part of every transaction done on a Visa card," said Gil Luria, an analyst at Wedbush Securities. "All Visa has to do is be in the middle and coordinate with everybody."

Visa consistently ranks among top corporate performers, with at least 19 consecutive quarters of double-digit earnings growth. Its shares have risen about 518% since going public at 44 in 2008, splitting 4-for-1 this year and now trading at about 68. Visa has a stellar IBD Composite Rating of 96 out of 99.
"We look at it like we've had this amazing past," Scharf told IBD. "We sit here today and think our future is more exciting than the past we've had."

What's perhaps even more remarkable is that despite Visa's dominant position, cash still rules much of the world. Cash is used in about half of U.S. transactions. Outside the U.S., 85% of consumers are estimated to pay with cash.

"There is a lot of growth potential in the United States and it is more pronounced internationally," said Sanjay Sakhrani, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. "There is still a long runway for growth."

In terms of growing shareholder value, a possible $20 billion merger with Visa Europe, spun off from the main company just before Visa's IPO, may steepen Visa's growth trajectory. Merger talks reportedly have been ongoing since the spring, but Scharf declined to discuss the subject. Visa Europe, which deployed chip card tech long before Visa, claims about 52% of the European market. MasterCard claims about 26% in Europe.
Defying The Larger Market
In a volatile, down year for the market, Visa has been a leader in boosting value. Visa shares are up 3.7% so far this year, while the S&P 500 is down about 8.3% in 2015.

Visa's net revenue in fiscal '14 rose 8% to $12.7 billion, and analysts expect 2015 to settle up at $13.87 billion. Adjusted net income in 2014 rose 15% to $5.7 billion, yielding earnings per share up 19% to $2.27 adjusted for the split. Analysts expect a 15% rise to $2.62 EPS in 2015, ending Sept. 30.

Visa has its challenges beyond hackers. Merchants have sued Visa, accusing it of unfairly charging excessive fees. Currently, Target, Amazon (AMZN) and other retailers are suing in federal court, asking for a $5.7 billion antitrust settlement to be vacated.

They argue the settlement forces them to give up rights to sue over some of Visa's practices and policies. The merchants also claim that Visa and MasterCard fixed the fees they were charged each time customers used their cards. About 8,000 merchants opted out of the settlement, approved in 2013, and more than 30 lawsuits against Visa and MasterCard are still pending in that case.
A federal appeals court in New York is currently weighing whether to approve the settlement.
Scharf downplayed the litigation, stressing the value that the Visa network provides for all of its customers — big and small.

"Merchants are as important to us as the banks are, as are the acquirers," he said.As cybercrime strikes with worrisome frequency, Visa (V) is deploying new technology and services to keep digital thieves at bay and secure its position as the world's largest money card processor.The late-2013 data security breach at Target (TGT) was a game changer for American merchants, exposing 40 million debit and credit card accounts, costing the big-box retailer tens of millions of dollars and the CEO his job. It accelerated the move to chip-embedded cards in the U.S., which had lagged behind foreign money-card innovation.Target wasn't the only big victim. Home Depot (HD), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Michaels (MIK), Berkshire Hathaway's (BRKB) Dairy Queen and others also have been badly compromised in the last two years.Fighting cybercrime has become an endless war as hackers grow more sophisticated, but Wednesday is the last day of blame-sharing.
