Anyone wondering why foreign direct investment in China keeps declining — down last year at the sharpest rate since the 2008 financial crisis, according to the Financial Times — needs to look no further than the Beijing government's invidious treatment of foreign companies trying to do business there.

It's an issue that threatens to undercut what China desperately needs to pull out of its current economic doldrums (its premier, Li Keqiang, has set next year's growth rate at 7%, the lowest target in a decade and a half): more direct investment from successful and innovative non-Chinese firms, especially American firms.Indeed, China's growing hostility to American businesses represents a major stumbling block to further economic ties between the two countries. A survey last fall by the American Chamber of Commerce in China found that 60% of American businesses feel less welcome on the mainland, and 49% say that the Chinese government has been singling out foreign-owned firms for adverse treatment.The battle between Chinese authorities and Google, and the Chinese allegations that Apple has been price-gouging and spying on Chinese citizens using its iPhones, are well-known — as is the fact that Apple made the charges go away by agreeing to store data from its Chinese iPhone users in China, which will allow the government to spy on them instead.But not many are aware of the even more egregious case of OSI, a food-processing firm that spent $750 million building up its Husi Food unit over two decades to serve McDonald's and other fast-food restaurants in China.This is no fly-by-night operation. The American-based firm set up the first food processing plant in Beijing in 1991, followed by plants in Langfang and Shanghai. In 2008, it started to provide high-quality food products to Yum Brands, whose Chinese division services 4,800 KFCs and 1,600 Pizza Huts across the country.Then suddenly, last summer, the city's Food and Drug Administration arrested six workers in its Shanghai plant and closed the plant. A video on government-owned Dragon TV, showing workers making chicken nuggets and patties from expired meat, triggered the action.OSI officials, however, have a very different account of what happened. They argue that the "workers" were in fact Dragon TV reporters (according to Reuters, a worker at a Shanghai employment agency actually saw an undercover reporter trying to get a job at the Husi factory).The company further alleges that the reporters masquerading as employees even threw meat on the floor while Dragon's cameras recorded them picking it up and re-using it.In any case, six employees were arrested and remain in jail, even though no formal charges have been brought. Another 350 employees in the Shanghai plant were laid off.Meanwhile, OSI Group's stock took a severe hit, as did Yum Brands. So did Husi Food's reputation. Indeed, the McDonald's China division has dropped Husi as a supplier.OSI has been working hard to get itself back into what had been one of its most important growth markets, but Shanghai authorities are determined to play hardball.Although OSI Chairman Sheldon Lavin issued a public statement that what happened at the plant was "terribly wrong, and I am appalled," the general feeling is that OSI and Husi Food have been railroaded.When Chinese authorities said in January that their investigation was leading them to order the destruction of "questionable products" recalled from Husi Food, OSI quickly pointed out that the recall had been entirely voluntary and that the products being destroyed never met the China Food and Drug Administration's definition of "questionable products."In short, the OSI battle is looking like the war of intimidation that foreign firms all too often face in doing business in China these days, from charges of price gouging to food tampering.Most give in and drop their prices or submit to the charges and pay a fine. They are aware that state-run regulatory agencies can trigger an avalanche of bad publicity that can wreck a foreign-owned business in a matter of days, as happened to Husi — and run up costs in the hundreds of millions of dollars, as happened to OSI.China law expert Dan Harris recently testified to the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission on the increasingly chilly investment climate in China. He pointed out that many U.S. firms face unfair competition by following rules concerning employment and taxes that Chinese firms routinely ignore.In the end, however, the war on business is hurting China more than the U.S.From 2002 to 2012, China was the country where most international business executives wanted to do direct foreign investment. In 2013, it lost top place to the United States; in 2014, confidence in China slid even further.According to the South China Morning Post, nearly one in four American companies planning to invest $250 million or more in China have dropped or postponed plans, even though most still see the country as a future growth market and are eager to do business there.If China intends to grow out of its enormous debt problems, it will need foreign investment. Yet by biting the hand that feeds it, in OSI's case almost literally, it's only hurting its own future. Herman is a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute.

The stock market closed lower Monday as retailers had a bumpy session. The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.5%.Volume rose, which was no surprise after Friday's half session. Declining stocks led advancers by 9-to-7 on the NYSE and 9-to-8 on the Nasdaq in the stock market today.Transportation, medical and some retail industry groups were among the weakest Monday. Energy and mining stocks were some of the strongest.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) gapped down to a 9% loss, sinking right back below its 50-day moving average. An analyst at FBR Capital Markets downgraded Lululemon to underperform from market perform and cut the price target to 42 from 55.Investors grew pessimistic about the early holiday shopping indications. Other retailers that sold off in heavy trading included Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Urban Outfitters (URBN).Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) had the worst loss on the IBD 50, down about 3%. A breakout bid past a 588.15 buy point has unraveled.After the close, UnitedHealth Group (UNH) said that it is backing its forecast of earnings of about $6 a share in 2015 and $7.10 to $7.30 for 2016. Revenues for 2016 are projected to be $180 billion to $181 billion.The health insurer warned Nov. 19 of an earnings hit from its ObamaCare exchange-related business, citing higher medical costs from its individual market customers and a soft enrollment outlook.UnitedHealth shares rose slightly in extended trading.Several economic reports are due out Tuesday. Manufacturing reports from purchasing managers and the Institute for Supply Management are due out in the morning. Automakers will report their November sales.Earnings reports Tuesday include Fifth Street Finance (FSC) and Guidewire Software (GWRE).Follow Juan Carlos Arancibia on Twitter @IBD_JArancibia.

Wall Street anticipates fired-up third-quarter results when Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reports on Monday after the close, but how much earnings growth will investors see from the exceedingly popular eatery chain?
Shares of the casual dining chain, known for their burritos and tacos made with fresh ingredients, fell 1.1% to 638.95 in the stock market on Friday.
Earnings are expected to jump 44.4% to $3.84 a share, and revenue is seen rising 28.3% to $1.06 billion.

The $20-billion company has enjoyed a streak of successes, with shares rising more than 20% from 532.78 at the start of the calendar year. The company has an IBD EPS Rating of 93, which means its per-share earnings growth has outpaced 93% of all other publicly traded companies, and ranks first in the IBD Retail-Restaurants industry group.
Chipotle's same-restaurant sales should perk up 16.6%, according to analysts, with Wunderlich Securities seeing sunny-side-up trends through next summer for the country's eateries.

Though Chipotle and sports-centric Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) have been performing well, other restaurant stocks have struggled recently. Taco Bell and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) missed Q3 views following the summer's meat scandal in China, and Panera Bread (PNRA) is seen by some analysts as disappointing expectations due to "underwhelming" traffic.
RELATED:
What Restaurant Stocks Could Heat Up Again This Year?

McDonald's didn't try to supersize its disappointing third-quarter results Tuesday, with its CEO saying the fast food giant must "fundamentally change." But winning over new diners without alienating its existing base won't be easy.

The world's No. 1 restaurant operator earned $1.35 excluding a 26-cent tax-related charge for an unfavorable foreign court ruling. That's down 11% vs. a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.37.
Revenue fell 4.6% to $6.99 billion, below views of $7.18 billion.

U.S. and global same-store sales fell 3.3% vs. a year earlier, reflecting a decline in guest traffic, meat supplier issues in Asia and blowback from tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine. Slowing economies in China and Europe didn't help.
McDonald's (MCD) stock fell 0.6% to 91.01 after hitting 89.70 intraday.

President and CEO Don Thompson didn't attempt to spin the results, saying they "reflect a significant decline from a year ago" and promising "decisive action to fundamentally change the way we approach our business."
More Local Tastes Planned
Thompson stressed plans for more menu choices, more local autonomy in the U.S. to cater to customers' tastes, and modernizing decor and technology.
McDonald's has introduced Apple (AAPL) Pay mobile payment technology at 14,000 U.S. locations and added self-order kiosks in France, Australia and elsewhere, he said.

The burger giant also launched an advertising campaign letting people make fun of and ask what's in McDonald's food, which many young adults see as unhealthy compared to fast-casual fare from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA). (Chipotle shares fell 7% Tuesday despite reporting blowout earnings late Monday, mostly on concerns that growth must slow.)
But raising the quality of McDonald's food would hit customers in their wallets.
"It is very hard to do that without raising the prices," said Lynne Collier, an analyst at Sterne, Agee & Leach. "It's not going to be an easy fix."
McDonald's prices already rose 3% in the 12 months to June 30.
Low-income consumers, a mainstay of fast-food eateries, were hit hard by the Great Recession and continue to struggle amid a sluggish recovery.
Yum, Coke Also Struggle

Yum Brands (YUM), parent of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, earlier this month issued disappointing quarterly earnings and full-year guidance. Much of that reflects continued fallout from China's meat scandal on KFC there. But the fast-food operator also has struggled to win over U.S. customers with higher-quality fare.

Coca-Cola (KO) shares suffered their biggest intraday loss since 2008, falling 6% to 40.68 after reporting soft Q3 earnings Tuesday. The soda king, like Yum and McDonald's, is coping with an economic slowdown overseas and health concerns at home.
McDonald's remains a well-liked dividend stock with a long-track record as one of the great U.S. business success stories.
"They are a powerful cash flow generator," said Efraim Levy, an equity analyst at S&P Capital IQ. "That's not going away."
Levy said that the key to McDonald's growth is "creating a different experience ... from what it is today (that) doesn't stray too much from its core."
Tweaks are needed, not major surgery, Levy added.

"Not all their consumers are that cost-conscious. They want the flavor and the convenience."McDonald's didn't try to supersize its disappointing third-quarter results Tuesday, with its CEO saying the fast food giant must "fundamentally change." As the fast-food breakfast competition heats up, McDonald's (MCD) has applied for a trademark on the term "McBrunch."

Expanding breakfast hours past the almost-industry standard 11 a.m. cutoff would give McDonald's more opportunities to compete in an increasingly crowded space, though the company has not officially announced expanded hours.

The trademark filing took place in July, and it is "highly premature" to speculate on McDonald's brunch plans, spokeswoman Lisa McComb told Bloomberg and USA Today, adding, "we routinely file intent to use trademark applications as a regular course of business."
Shares changed little on the stock market today.
Burger King (BKW) reportedly experimented with a brunch menu that included juice-and-Sprite mock-mosas and a ciabatta sandwich, but the offerings never went national.
A McDonald's brunch could face similar challenges, and its McBrunch trademark filing comes as other fast-food players attempt to grab more morning business.
In August, Burger King inked a deal to buy Canadian coffee and donut chain Tim Hortons (THI) for $11 billion, in part to expand its breakfast reach.
Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell launched a breakfast menu about six months ago, offering waffle tacos and breakfast burritos. Several days ago, the Mexican fast-food chain began testing a biscuit taco.

Meantime, McDonald's has been struggling to draw customers. On Tuesday, it reported a 3.7% drop in August same-store sales and gave Q3 earnings guidance that was below consensus views, sending the shares to a 19-month low.
McDonald's has an IBD Composite Rating of 33 out of 99, meaning two-thirds of stocks in the market perform better than the company as measured by technical and fundamental factors.

Restaurant industry sales rebounded in August from the weak showing of the past several months, a sign that better days could be ahead for the nation's eateries, according to a report from Wunderlich Securities analyst Robert Derrington.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) is among Derrington's favorite restaurant picks — he rates it a buy. The sports bar and eatery operator holds an IBD Composite Rating of 91 out of a highest-possible 99. Another of Derrington's several picks is Jack In The Box (JACK), which gets an IBD Composite Rating of 86.

IBD Leaderboard and IBD 50 stock Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has the highest Composite Rating of IBD's Retail-Restaurants group with a 98. The largest names in the group by market cap are McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX), followed by Yum Brands (YUM) and Chipotle.
Late Tuesday, two key industry sales indexes were released, showing that August sales trends improved "considerably" from the very weak trend of the past several months, Derrington noted.

"While both the Knapp Track Casual Dining Index and Black Box Intelligence Sales indices have been especially volatile in recent months, the August improvement potentially could mark a period of improving industry sales possibly through next summer as the industry laps especially weak trends from last year," Derrington wrote. "With the modestly improving macro economic backdrop, including improvements in consumer confidence and sentiment, these improved August industry trends could potentially usher in a period of improving industry SSS (same-store-sales) through summer 2015."
Casual-dining restaurant operators Red Robin (RRGB) and Brinker International (EAT) are also among Derrington's favorite picks — he rates each a buy.

The Black Box Intelligence (BBI) overall Industry Index improved significantly for August, with same-store sales for the month's index up 2.1%, with traffic down 0.5%. Derrington says this was the strongest BBI industry same-store sales performance since February 2012. On a two-year basis, August same-store sales improved 230 basis point to +1.9% vs. the July two-year trend of -0.4%.

Derrington also points out: "The BBI index, which collects a broader cross-section of industry sales data from fast-food, fast-casual, and casual dining restaurant companies, also faces relatively easy comparisons through June 2015, lapping relatively flat nominal SSS through next summer," Derrington said.

The improved industry trends follow "very weak and volatile" same-store-sales trends of both June and July, Derrington noted. He says the two months were believed to have been impacted by factors such as weak consumer spending, delayed school dismissals in June, and the much wetter and cooler weather in both June and July vs. last year's unusually hot summer.
"Aided by August's recent substantial improvement in consumer confidence, these better August industry SSS trends could mark a period of improving industry sales through next summer," he added.

On the casual dining front, which includes operators like Buffalo Wild Wings and Brinker, the Knapp Track (KT) Casual Dining (CD) index reported its first month of positive same-store sales since May 2013. August nominal same-store sales were up 0.5% and traffic was down 2.0%.

Derrington says on a two-year basis, casual dining industry sales improved "dramatically" in August and were 400 basis points better than July 2014. Casual dining industry same-store sales comparisons remain "relatively easy" through next June, he adds.

The improved industry showing in August came despite weakness from the industry's biggest player, McDonald's. On Tuesday, it reported its weakest monthly same-store sales results since March 2013, Derrington says. The disappointing showing sent McDonald's shares sliding Tuesday. The company's August same-store sales slipped 3.7% vs. a year earlier. U.S. same-store sales were down 2.8%.Restaurant industry sales rebounded in August from the weak showing of the past several months, a sign that better days could be ahead for the nation's eateries, according to a report from Wunderlich Securities analyst Robert Derrington.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) is among Derrington's favorite restaurant picks — he rates it a buy. The sports bar and eatery operator holds an IBD Composite Rating of 91 out of a highest-possible 99. Another of Derrington's several picks is Jack In The Box (JACK), which gets an IBD Composite Rating of 86.IBD Leaderboard and IBD 50 stock Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has the highest Composite Rating of IBD's Retail-Restaurants group with a 98. The largest names in the group by market cap are McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX), followed by Yum Brands (YUM) and Chipotle.Late Tuesday, two key industry sales indexes were released, showing that August sales trends improved "considerably" from the very weak trend of the past several months, Derrington noted."While both the Knapp Track Casual Dining Index and Black Box Intelligence Sales indices have been especially volatile in recent months, the August improvement potentially could mark a period of improving industry sales possibly through next summer as the industry laps especially weak trends from last year," Derrington wrote. "With the modestly improving macro economic backdrop, including improvements in consumer confidence and sentiment, these improved August industry trends could potentially usher in a period of improving industry SSS (same-store-sales) through summer 2015."Casual-dining restaurant operators Red Robin (RRGB) and Brinker International (EAT) are also among Derrington's favorite picks — he rates each a buy.The Black Box Intelligence (BBI) overall Industry Index improved significantly for August, with same-store sales for the month's index up 2.1%, with traffic down 0.5%. Derrington says this was the strongest BBI industry same-store sales performance since February 2012. On a two-year basis, August same-store sales improved 230 basis point to +1.9% vs. the July two-year trend of -0.4%.Derrington also points out: "The BBI index, which collects a broader cross-section of industry sales data from fast-food, fast-casual, and casual dining restaurant companies, also faces relatively easy comparisons through June 2015, lapping relatively flat nominal SSS through next summer," Derrington said.The improved industry trends follow "very weak and volatile" same-store-sales trends of both June and July, Derrington noted. He says the two months were believed to have been impacted by factors such as weak consumer spending, delayed school dismissals in June, and the much wetter and cooler weather in both June and July vs. last year's unusually hot summer."Aided by August's recent substantial improvement in consumer confidence, these better August industry SSS trends could mark a period of improving industry sales through next summer," he added.On the casual dining front, which includes operators like Buffalo Wild Wings and Brinker, the Knapp Track (KT) Casual Dining (CD) index reported its first month of positive same-store sales since May 2013. August nominal same-store sales were up 0.5% and traffic was down 2.0%.Derrington says on a two-year basis, casual dining industry sales improved "dramatically" in August and were 400 basis points better than July 2014. Casual dining industry same-store sales comparisons remain "relatively easy" through next June, he adds.The improved industry showing in August came despite weakness from the industry's biggest player, McDonald's. On Tuesday, it reported its weakest monthly same-store sales results since March 2013, Derrington says. The disappointing showing sent McDonald's shares sliding Tuesday. The company's August same-store sales slipped 3.7% vs. a year earlier. U.S. same-store sales were down 2.8%.
Starbucks (SBUX) shares rose Thursday as analysts sounded bullish about its future, even if domestic same-store sales slumped, which they're not.

UBS analyst Keith Siegner said that the coffee house's expansion into other sales outlets and its initiatives to drive traffic could counter any downturn in comparable store sales in its Americas unit. He sees Starbucks sustaining a same-store sales increase of 5% in the region. Last quarter Starbucks generated a 6% rise in comps in the Americas.
Siegner upgraded Starbucks to buy from neutral on the brighter outlook.
Starbucks shares rose 2% by early afternoon to 77.04 in the stock market today, Thursday.

The breakfast space has become crowded; even Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell joined the mix. So Starbucks is branching out into wine to get customers in the door in the evening. The company plans to serve alcoholic beverages at 40 locations across the country by the end of the year and already opened spots in Chicago, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Washington, D.C.

With tea, Starbucks is also expanding its nonalcoholic beverage options. Earlier this year CEO Howard Schultz estimated the global tea industry is worth about $90 billion, and Starbucks could gain a lot of ground with its $620 million purchase of Teavana more than a year ago.
The Retail-Restaurant group is ranked No. 117 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.
Starbucks earns a 66 out of 99 Composite Rating. IBD's Composite Rating rates stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength.

The U.S. and Asia aren't lovin' it. McDonald's (MCD) same-store restaurant sales fell in July. The fast-food chain said sales at stores open 13 months or more fell 2.5% last month, worse than the 1.1% dip analysts at Consensus Metrix were expecting, according to Reuters. "Although July's results were not in-line with McDonald's expectations, we intend to strengthen our performance…
News poured out of China on Monday, sending a handful of China-related stocks both up and down sharply.

Yum Brands (YUM) and McDonald's (MCD) received the short straw Monday, as a new food safety scare in China gained momentum. Both companies issued apologies to customers after a TV report led Chinese authorities to shut down Shanghai Husi Food, a supplier of chicken meat and other products to both chains.
The report described unsafe and unsanitary practices among workers at a Husi plant. The company is a subsidiary of the privately held Illinois-based OSI Group.
China's $174 billion fast-food market is Yum's largest, and the third largest for McDonald's. Both companies were working to recover from an earlier food scare in 2012.
Yum shares fell 4% Monday. McDonald's dropped off more than 1%.

On the more positive side, Baidu (BIDU) received an upgrade from Morgan Stanley. Their report boosted China's largest search engine operator to overweight from equalweight and hoisted its price target to 239.30. Accelerating revenue growth — in the 50% range for the past three quarters — was a key element of the upgrade. The note cited acquisitions and improved monetization of both PC and mobile traffic.
The company blew past Q1 consensus earnings expectations. Views call for a 2% gain in Q2. Baidu is scheduled to report results Thursday evening.
The stock rose 3% Monday. It is extended 16% above a 170.89 buy point in a first-stage cup base.

Kandi Technologies (KNDI) skipped up 10% in very heavy trade. The volatile stock dived 52% in the five weeks to mid-April. It carved out a U-shaped bottom through early July, then rocketed 33% higher last week, after reporting a huge quarterly sales increase in Q2, up 174%. Monday's gain left the stock just below the flawed base's potential buy point of 22.50.

The company makes new energy vehicles, or NEVs. Part golf cart, part sedan, the vehicles are designed for short jaunts at slow speeds — not highway travel. A Seeking Alpha article Monday cited estimates that NEV sales in China would reach 50,000 this year — a 200% year-over-year gain. Kandi holds the leading share of that market. Recent sales growth has ramped up sharply after a weak 2013. McDonald's (MCD) U.S. comparable sales fell in May for the seventh straight month as breakfast competition heightened and eating habits changed.
The fast-food restaurant said Monday that sales at its U.S. stores opened the last 14 months fell 1% because of "ongoing broad-based challenges."
By early afternoon, shares fell 0.5% to 101.45 in the stock market today.

Customers' eating habits are shifting toward more fast-casual restaurants such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG). The burrito chain boasts organic and locally sourced veggies as well as "green" building designs.

To compete with Chipotle and Panera Bread (PNRA), McDonald's has expanded its healthy fare options to include more wraps and salads. But franchises complained that McDonald's introduced the items too quickly, slowing service and leading to increased mistakes with orders.
With the Egg McMuffin, McDonald's used to be the undisputed king of breakfast but competitors have been adding options for the that's often called the "most important meal of the day."
Earlier this year Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell introduced the waffle taco for breakfast and even ran an ad campaign that featured men named Ronald McDonald saying how much they liked the new taco.
Overall same-store sales rose 0.9%. McDonald's same-store sales in its Asia, Middle East and Africa division were up 2.5% as bird flu worries eased in China.
European same-store sales rose 0.4% on increased sales in the U.K. and France.
McDonald's is slated to release Q2 results on July 22.

McDonald's (MCD) and Yum Brands (YUM) are hoping that halting meat shipments from their Shanghai supplier will help offset consumer backlash over a report saying they may have sold outdated meat.
McDonald's, which operates nearly 2,000 restaurants in China, said on a company blog site that it had asked all of its outlets to stop using meat from Shanghai Husi Food Co.

Yum Brands, parent of the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains, separately said it also halted purchases from the supplier. Coffeehouse chain Starbucks (SBUX) also removed an item from its menu that reportedly contained meat from the supplier.

Chinese regulators suspended operations at Shanghai Husi the same day that Dragon TV, a local channel, said workers at the meat supplier's plant were repackaging and selling chicken and beef that had expired sell-by dates on them, according to a Bloomberg report.
McDonald's and Yum both apologized to customers, saying the move will result in short supplies of some menu items.
Both companies have faced similar controversies in China in recent years.

Yum, which ended 2013 with 4,563 KFC restaurants in China and more than 6,000 total including Pizza Hut and local branded chains, saw sales plunge in early 2013 as an outbreak of avian flu at Chinese poultry farms scared consumers away. A fresh outbreak last February threatened to scare away consumers again, but there were just a few cases and it quickly subsided.

In December 2012, China investigated claims that some Yum and McDonald's suppliers were injecting growth hormones and other drugs into chickens, violating China's food safety laws. Yum reportedly cut ties with 100 suppliers.
Yum shares skidded nearly 4% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market. McDonald's and Starbucks were both down about 1%.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which doesn't operate in China, was slated to report second-quarter earnings after the market close Monday.
Chipotle, the top-rated company in the 56-company restaurant group, and whose stock is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was down more than 1%.

Stocks opened lower Thursday and continued selling off throughout the session, with scores of leaders taking big hits as well, adding pressure to a market already under pressure.The Nasdaq slumped 2.1%. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials, meanwhile, both sank nearly 2%, plunging below their 50-day moving averages. Volume was sharply higher in the stock market today, according to preliminary data, indicating the big money was busy selling.Few groups were spared in the downdraft. Insurers, 3D printer makers and solar stocks were among the day's worst performers.Yum Brands (YUM) gapped down and fell 5% in busy turnover, nearing a six-month low. On Wednesday, the restaurant operator said in an SEC filing that a negative TV news report earlier this month of a Chinese meat supplier has caused "significant" and "negative" damage to sales at its restaurants in China. Analysts trimmed their 2014 and '15 earnings estimates as a result.On the upside, Tessera Technologies (TSRA) bucked the downtrend as it gapped up and soared 9% to a multiyear high in massive trade. Late Thursday, the fabless chipmaker said it entered new technology and patent license agreements with Micron Technology (MU).Among leading stocks, Arris Group (ARRS), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), GoPro (GPRO) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) all reported after the close.Argentina's debt default weighed on the market. Weekly jobless claims, however, offered some good news, falling a bit more than expected to 302,000.Economic data slated for Friday morning include the July jobs report, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey and the latest reading from the ISM manufacturing index.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.
Stocks slumped out of the starting gates Monday, as home sales, Black Friday returns and Chicago manufacturing data put pressure on opening trade.

The Nasdaq slipped furthest, down 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1% apiece. Small caps ran slightly against the grain, with the Russell 2000 rising 0.1% and the small-cap S&P 600 index up nearly 0.2% in early trade.
Volume was well above Friday morning's levels, no surprise in a lame-duck trading session after the Thanksgiving Day break.
The stock market today received no breaks from the early economic news.

Chicago Purchasing Managers Index dropped to 48.7 for November, Kingsbury International reported. That was sharply below October's 56.2 reading, as well as economist consensus expectations of 54. The gauge is generally taken as a precursor to the more closely watched Institute for Supply Management's PMI index, which is due out Tuesday morning.

Pending home sales ticked up a feeble 0.2% in October, the National Association of Realtors said. The gain was an improvement after two months of declines, but well below forecasts for a 1% increase. Pending home sales have flattened this fall, the NAR said in a release, as consumers face rising prices and a dwindling inventory of homes.

In stocks, Computer Sciences (CSC) jumped 22% as the company divided into two separate publicly traded operations. CSRA (CSRA) combines CSC's government-contractor business and the operations of SRA International, which CSC announced in August it would acquire. It begins trading Monday under the CSRA ticker. CSC's commercial operations continue to trade as CSC on the NYSE. CSRA shares traded up 6% in early action.

Retailers were taking some notable hits as early tallies begin to roll in from the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season. Under Armour (UA) and Urban Outfitters (URBN) each dropped 3%. Ugg maker Deckers Outdoor (DECK) dived 6%. Fashion designer Steve Madden (SHOO) dumped 4%.

Among IBD 50 stocks, TAL Education (XRS) jumped nearly 3%, bumping off another new high. The China-based chain of after-school tutoring clinics has gained in 13 of 15 recent sessions, in the process clearing a 38.75 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shares are now extended almost 15%.

Another China-based issue, Noah (NOAH), climbed nearly 2% for the group's second best gain. The asset-management firm has failed to decisively clear a 33.10 buy point in a flawed cup-with-handle base.

Nike (NKE) slipped more than 1% to take the IBD 50's worst early decline (also the largest decline among Dow stocks). CEO David Novak said on a conference call Tuesday that recent cases of avian flu in China, Yum's largest market with 50% of its sales, have not caused a…
Yum Brands names CEO,Ford names Mulally successor
Yum Brands (YUM) and Ford Motor (F), which have managed significant sales and profit growth since emerging from the Great Recession, announced a changing of the guard at the top, naming new CEOs.
Both companies are making the changes as they fight for market share globally, defending positions in the U.S. and China, the world's top consumer markets, and elsewhere.
Yum Brands, parent of the Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut fast food restaurant chains, said Greg Creed will become CEO on Jan. 1, 2015, replacing David Novak, who has served in the position since 1999.
Creed, who headed the Taco Bell franchise, is credited with creating the popular Doritos Locos Tacos campaign at Taco Bell, and turning around the chain's image.
Louisville, Ky.-based Yum has had mixed results in recent quarters as Taco Bell performed well in the U.S., but KFC and Pizza Hut have grappled with declining sales.

In China, Yum Brands' KFC is the top Western fast-food restaurant chain. But the company is recovering from issues in China, including outbreaks in recent years of avian flu, which scared some consumers away from KFC outlets.

Outgoing Yum CEO Novak will become executive chairman upon his retirement in January. Novak will form the office of the chairman, the company said, composed of himself, Vice Chairman Sam Su and Creed.
"This new office of the chairman will partner as a triumvirate on overall corporate strategy and leadership development," Novak said in a statement.
Yum shares are trading within range of an all-time intraday high 79.70 set on April 23. Shares were down 1% at 76.19 in afternoon trading in the stock market today Thursday.
Ford made its long-expected announcement of a successor to retiring Chief Executive Alan Mulally, 68, who took the reins in September 2006.
Ford named Chief Operating Officer Mark Fields to the post, effective July 1.
"Mark has transformed several of our operations around the world into much stronger businesses during his 25 years at Ford," Executive Chairman Bill Ford said.
Fields has big shoes to fill. Mulally is widely credited with Ford's dramatic post-recession turnaround.

Ford, the No. 2 U.S. automaker and the only major American car company that didn't file for bankruptcy protection during the recession, has generated 19 consecutive quarters of profitability and has closed the revenue gap with No. 1 General Motors (GM).
Ford was down 1% Thursday afternoon. High-end electric-car maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose more than 1%.

But the company is recovering from issues in China, including outbreaks in recent years of avian flu, which scared some consumers away from KFC outlets.Outgoing Yum CEO Novak will become executive chairman upon his retirement in January. McDonald's (MCD) hasn't let a recent slowdown in profit and sales growth affect its dividend payouts.
In Q4 last year, the fast-food giant boosted its quarterly payout by 4 cents to 81 cents per share, or $3.24 on an annual basis. The 3.2% dividend yield outpaces the S&P 500's 1.9%.
McDonald's is a member of the S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats index, companies that have consistently increased their annual payouts for the past 25 years. It has raised dividends each year since 1977.

The Oak Brook, Ill.-based chain last week reported Q1 EPS of $1.21, down 4% from the prior year and 3 cents below views. Sales rose 1.4% to $6.7 billion, also missing. Revenue growth has been stuck in a range between flat and 2% the past eight quarters. Profit declined for the first time in six quarters; analysts expect growth to resume in Q2 at 5%.

A five-year earnings stability factor of 4 on a scale of 0 (most stable) to 99 (least stable) reflects the company's steady track record. McDonald's has grown annual profit the past 11 years, with consensus estimates calling for a 4% gain this year and 8% the next.

Shares have been cooking up a saucer-shaped base with a potential 103.80 entry since striking a record high last April, and are 1% off its high. They rose 8% after clearing a 96.42 buy point from its previous base, a cup with handle, in March 2013.
McDonald's isn't the only eatery struggling with a slowdown. Retail-Restaurants, at No. 175 in Tuesday's issue, sits near the bottom of IBD's 197 industry groups.

While the burger chain has been stepping up its coffee offerings to better compete with the likes of Starbucks (SBUX) and Dunkin' Brands (DNKN), it is facing increased competition in the breakfast arena. Last month, Yum Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell entered the battle for early diners as it began serving up morning fare including egg burritos, Cinnabon Delights and Waffle Tacos.McDonald's (MCD) hasn't let a recent slowdown in profit and sales growth affect its dividend payouts.In Q4 last year, the fast-food giant boosted its quarterly payout by 4 cents to 81 cents per share, or $3.24 on an annual basis. The food fight on Wall Street keeps expanding, and investors signaled that they expect it to get even bigger. Tyson Foods, salivating over Hillshire Brands' prepared foods, offered on Thursday to acquire it for $6.8 billion, including assumed debt, or $50 a share in cash.

That trumps the $6.4 billion, $45-a-share cash bid from Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) for Hillshire (HSH) earlier this week. That in turn came on the heels of Hillshire's proposed $6.6 billion merger with Pinnacle Foods (PF).

"Hillshire's bid for Pinnacle last week (plus) the end of tax implications from Sara Lee spin are the key catalysts from a timing perspective," said Miller Tabak analyst Tim Tiberio via email. "HSH is attractive to TSN & PPC, as the company would enable them to fulfill their ambition of becoming a leading packaged meat company (higher margins, more stable cash flow and leading brand talent from Hillshire)."
Household Names

While top chicken processor Tyson (TSN) has several brands for steak, tortillas and deli meats, Hillshire would bulk up its prepared foods. It boasts several popular supermarket lines, including Ball Park hot dogs, Sara Lee frozen bakery goods, and Jimmy Dean and Hillshire Farm sausages.
Adding Hillshire also would add "significant synergy opportunities in production, logistics and sales," Tyson said in an investors' presentation Thursday.
Stephens analyst Farha Aslam also sees takeover synergies in a research note, singling out Tyson's pork business as one that would benefit from "better raw material utilization."

Pilgrim's sees Hillshire brands adding retail strength to its existing food-service and grocery-store lines. On the food-service end, Pilgrim's supplies fresh chicken to delis and restaurants, and prepared chicken to chains like Yum! Brands (YUM) and Chick-fil-A. Pilgrim's also has expressed interest in pursuing "joint opportunities in school lunch and institutional" areas.
Bidding War Likely
Hillshire will reportedly review the Tyson offer in addition to the Pilgrim's bid, but more feathers may be shed before a new pecking order is set.

"Based on our indirect following of (Pilgrim's Pride majority owner) JBS over the years, we would find it highly doubtful that the management team will let Hillshire go without, at least, another round of bidding," Tiberio wrote in a note. "JBS' aspiration to use Pilgrim's balance sheet as a growth vehicle in North America is very well known."
Hillshire shares rose 17% to 52.76. That's significantly above Tyson's offer, suggesting investors expect a beefed-up bid. Hillshire is up 42.5% this week.
Tyson shares rose 6% to 43.25.
Pilgrim's Pride fell 1% to 25.09.
Earlier in May, Hillshire offered to buy Pinnacle Foods for $6.6 billion including debt. Pinnacle brands include Vlasic pickles, Duncan Hines cake mixes and Birds Eye frozen vegetables.
The Tyson and Pilgrim offers for Hillshire assume the Pinnacle deal won't happen. Pinnacle shares edged up Thursday but fell 5% Tuesday on Pilgrim's bid.

Tyson's fellow chicken processor Sanderson Farms (SAFM) said Thursday that it earned $2.21 a share, up 108% from a year earlier and beating fiscal Q2 views by 51 cents. Sales rose 6% $660.72 million, beating views of $625.7 million. Shares rose 3% to 90.34, hitting a new high intraday.The food fight on Wall Street keeps expanding, and investors signaled that they expect it to get even bigger. Although investors worry about less-robust growth in China, several U.S. corporate giants hailed Q1 demand in the world's second-largest economy.China has proven to be a strong engine for Apple (AAPL), with its new partner China Mobile (CHL) helping push fiscal Q2 iPhone sales to more than 43 million, far more than expected. The $9.2 billion that China added to Apple's coffers comprised nearly 25% of the company's total quarterly revenue, up 13% from a year earlier.Caterpillar (CAT), the giant construction-equipment manufacturer, has struggled with a global commodity slump that's hit mining-equipment demand. Overall sales were flat — actually ending a five-quarter decline.But China sales rose 30% vs. a year earlier. CEO Doug Oberhelman credits increased dealer deliveries and the favorable impact of dealer inventory changes.Economic growth in China of around 7.5% this year "should support improvements in the machine industry and increase commodity demand."Yum! Brands (YUM), parent of the KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut restaurant chains, says that its China-division sales grew 17% year over year, with restaurant margins increasingly almost 7% and operating profit up 80%. Yum adds that it expects to open at least 700 restaurants in China this year.The company is seeing improvement from a year earlier, when a chicken health scare scared jittery diners and investors. CEO David Novak cited KFC in China as "the most significant driver" of Yum's strong bounce back in the first quarter.Global casino giant Las Vegas Sands (LVS) topped Q1 forecasts Thursday, with strong growth in earnings and revenue driven in part by Sands Macau, its majority-owned unit in China's gaming mecca. Sands Macau revenue climbed 35%, and net income rose 66%. More than 17 million visits to its Macau facilities during Q1 delivered a record $939.8 million of adjusted property EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), said CEO Sheldon Adelson in a statement.Starbucks (SBUX) saw net revenues in its China/Asia-Pacific region grow 24% year over year to $265.3 million during its fiscal Q2, driven in part by nearly 700 stores opening over the past year. Comparable store sales were up 7%.United Technologies (UTX) says that new equipment orders at its Otis Elevator unit increased 9% from Q1 '13, led by 27% growth in China.McDonald's (MCD), which reports lackluster Q1 earnings — blamed on lower U.S. same-store sales and unusually severe winter weather throughout much of the United States — still reports solid sales in China. Comparable sales grew 6.6% for the first quarter, and McDonald's plans to open 300 new restaurants there this year.

Starbucks only met earnings estimates late Thursday, but same-store sales growth was a positive as other restaurants struggled to get customers in the door. The coffeehouse giant has its sights on expanding further beyond java. Fiscal Q2 earnings rose 17% to 56 cents, matching analyst estimates. Shares of fast food giant Yum Brands (YUM) were down Wednesday after Wells Fargo lowered its price target to $73-$75 from $75-$78, citing a resurgence of avian flu in China.The parent of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell sold off hard last year amid an outbreak of avian flu that caused fears among Chinese consumers of tainted chicken at KFC outlets.Yum gets more than 50% of its revenue from China, and the stock had already taken a pounding this month after its Pizza Hut division's same-store sales fell in December.Prospects for recovery brightened when it was upgraded by RBC Capital Markets to "top pick," a notch above "outperform," on Jan. 7. RBC also raised its price target to $87 from $85, saying it expected sales in China to rise in the second half of the year as avian flu fears subsided.But Wells Fargo said in its client note Wednesday that recent reports indicated at least 95 cases of the H7N9 avian flu strain had been found in China this month vs. 144 for all of 2013.The note projected "at least a modest avian flu head wind" impacting Yum earnings results, but the analysts kept their market perform rating on the stock.The report may also raise red flags for McDonald's (MCD), which sells chicken products at outlets in China.Yum, which will release Q4 results Feb. 3, saw its shares drop 2.6% on the stock market today. McDonald's was off 1%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

A new report on the restaurant industry shows a sharp rise in the number of Americans dining out vs. prior years and a slight increase in customer satisfaction, with eateries run by Darden Restaurants (DRI) and others rating high in their respective categories.

According to the 2014 American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) report, released today, Tuesday, Americans ate out an average of four meals per week last year, a 60% increase since the end of the Great Recession.
In addition, the report said, consumers are "more likely to spend on dining out as the economy improves, and higher levels of customer satisfaction help as well."
The ACSI groups restaurants into two categories: full service and limited service. It rates them on a scale of 100 total points.
The full-service category includes Darden, owner of the Olive Garden and, until recently, Red Lobster. It also includes Brinker International (EAT), owner of Chili's and Maggiano's Little Italy.
Full-service restaurants had an overall score of 82 for 2014, up slightly from 81 in 2013.
"This year's small gain is driven by improvement in smaller chains and restaurants, which make up the bulk of the sit-down industry," the ACSI report said.
Among large chains owned by publicly traded companies, Olive Garden had the highest score in 2014: 80, down from 83 in 2013. Chili's had a score of 74 in 2014, down from 78 a year earlier.
The limited-service category includes fast-food and fast-casual brands like Yum! Brands' (YUM) Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut; McDonald's (MCD); Starbucks (SBUX); and Burger King Worldwide (BKW).
Overall, limited-service restaurants scored an 80 on the 2014 ACSI report, matching its score from 2013. Both results represent an all-time high in the ASCI survey.

"Fast food is now a bit further behind the full-service restaurant category, but the industry still matches its all-time ACSI high," the report said. "Strong and stable customer satisfaction is a big change for an industry that was mired in the high 60s to low 70s throughout the 1990s."
Among big chains owned by publicly traded firms, Papa John's International (PZZA) and Yum!'s Pizza Hut had the highest scores, both at 82.
Industry heavyweights Starbucks and McDonald's lagged a bit behind, with scores of 76 and 71, respectively. Starbucks ranked No. 7 among the big chains, while McDonald's ranked No. 12.
Smaller limited-service chains were lumped together into an aggregate group and collectively had a score of 84 in 2014, up from 82 in 2013.

"A 2% gain to an all-time high ACSI score of 84 for smaller chains — including brands like Panera Bread (PNRA) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) in the rapidly growing fast-casual segment — is enough to offset drops for many of the largest fast food companies," the ACSI report said.
The report is based on interviews with nearly 4,600 customers who were chosen at random and contacted via telephone and email between Jan. 13 and March 11.

Customers were asked to evaluate their recent purchase and consumption experiences with the largest companies by market share within each of the measured categories, plus an aggregate of all other smaller brands not measured individually by name in the ACSI.A new report on the restaurant industry shows a sharp rise in the number of Americans dining out vs. prior years and a slight increase in customer satisfaction, with eateries run by Darden Restaurants (DRI) and others rating high in their respective categories.According to the 2014 American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) report, released today, Tuesday, Americans ate out an average of four meals per week last year, a 60% increase since the end of the Great Recession.In addition, the report said, consumers are "more likely to spend on dining out as the economy improves, and higher levels of customer satisfaction help as well."The ACSI groups restaurants into two categories: full service and limited service. Stocks were holding onto early gains by midday Tuesday, but volume was starting to trail off as the market sought to recover from Monday's sell-off. The market was digesting a slew of earnings reports.
The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.4%. Volume was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.

Upscale retailer Michael Kors (KORS) was the star of the day. It was up 17% after reporting earnings growth of 73% with sales up 59%, well above estimates. It gave cheery guidance. The stock gapped back up through its 50-day moving average and was trading at an all-time high.

Yum Brands (YUM), owner of the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC brands, rose 9% after reporting a 4% gain in earnings. That was its first earnings gain in four quarters. The stock broke back through its 200-day moving average and has been an underperformer in recent years.
Former leader ARM Holdings (ARMH) was down 6%, but off its lows of the morning. The British chipmaker reported a 30% gain in EPS, which equaled analysts' estimates.

Losses among IBD 50 stocks were moderate. Ambarella (AMBA) slipped furthest, down 3% to just below its 10-week moving average. It is in the fifth week of a consolidation.Stocks were holding onto early gains by midday Tuesday, but volume was starting to trail off as the market sought to recover from Monday's sell-off. Shares of McDonald's (MCD) were flat soon after the opening bell in the stock market today following the fast-food giant's weaker-than-expected quarterly sales amid a slowdown in customer traffic.
The world's biggest restaurant chain was hurt by severe winter weather in the U.S. during the fourth quarter as well as a drop in its global business.
Overall Q4 revenue grew 2% from the prior year to $7.09 billion, below estimates for $7.11 billion. Earnings climbed 1% to $1.40 a share, topping views by a penny.
It has been two years since McDonald's has delivered a double-digit gain on the top or bottom lines.

Global same-store sales declined 0.1% during the quarter as a 1% same-store sales gain in Europe was offset by a 1.4% decline in the U.S. and a 2.4% dip in Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa. Each of those numbers fell short of analyst estimates.
In December, comps fell 1.2%, with U.S. comps down 3.8%.
For the full year, global comps rose 0.2%.

In a statement, Chief Executive Don Thompson called 2013 "a challenging year," but said McDonald's begins 2014 "with a renewed focus on the global growth priorities that are most impactful" to its customers.
"We are uniting consumer insights with innovation and consistent execution to optimize our menu, modernize the customer experience and broaden accessibility to Brand McDonald's," Thompson said.
McDonald's shares were unchanged at 94.88 in early trading Thursday. The stock is down about 3% since the beginning of the year.
Other fast-food companies, which face many of the same challenges as McDonald's, are due to report earnings next month.

Yum Brands (YUM), which owns the Taco Bell and KFC franchises, is slated to report Q4 results on Feb. 3. Analysts expect EPS to decline 4% to 80 cents and sales to rise 3% to $4.26 billion. If that happens, it would be the fourth straight quarter of lower earnings.

Burger King Worldwide (BKW) is due to report the week of Feb. 10-14. Fourth-quarter earnings are expected to be flat at 23 cents a share, while sales should dip 33% to $270.3 million. That would mark the fifth straight quarter of 30%-or-higher sales declines amid a global refurnishing effort.

Wendy's (WEN) is due to report Q4 results on Feb. 27. Analysts expect earnings to dip 11% to 8 cents a share, while sales are seen falling 4% to $602.2 million. If that happens, it would end a run of four straight quarters of sales and earnings gains.Shares of McDonald's (MCD) were flat soon after the opening bell in the stock market today following the fast-food giant's weaker-than-expected quarterly sales amid a slowdown in customer traffic.The world's biggest restaurant chain was hurt by severe winter weather in the U.S. during the fourth quarter as well as a drop in its global business.Overall Q4 revenue grew 2% from the prior year to $7.09 billion, below estimates for $7.11 billion. Earnings climbed 1% to $1.40 a share, topping views by a penny.It has been two years since McDonald's has delivered a double-digit gain on the top or bottom lines.Global same-store sales declined 0.1% during the quarter as a 1% same-store sales gain in Europe was offset by a 1.4% decline in the U.S. and a 2.4% dip in Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa. Each of those numbers fell short of analyst estimates.In December, comps fell 1.2%, with U.S. comps down 3.8%.For the full year, global comps rose 0.2%.In a statement, Chief Executive Don Thompson called 2013 "a challenging year," but said McDonald's begins 2014 "with a renewed focus on the global growth priorities that are most impactful" to its customers."We are uniting consumer insights with innovation and consistent execution to optimize our menu, modernize the customer experience and broaden accessibility to Brand McDonald's," Thompson said.McDonald's shares were unchanged at 94.88 in early trading Thursday. The stock is down about 3% since the beginning of the year.Other fast-food companies, which face many of the same challenges as McDonald's, are due to report earnings next month.Yum Brands (YUM), which owns the Taco Bell and KFC franchises, is slated to report Q4 results on Feb. 3. Analysts expect EPS to decline 4% to 80 cents and sales to rise 3% to $4.26 billion. If that happens, it would be the fourth straight quarter of lower earnings.Burger King Worldwide (BKW) is due to report the week of Feb. 10-14. Fourth-quarter earnings are expected to be flat at 23 cents a share, while sales should dip 33% to $270.3 million. That would mark the fifth straight quarter of 30%-or-higher sales declines amid a global refurnishing effort.Wendy's (WEN) is due to report Q4 results on Feb. 27. Analysts expect earnings to dip 11% to 8 cents a share, while sales are seen falling 4% to $602.2 million. If that happens, it would end a run of four straight quarters of sales and earnings gains.

Tyson Foods (TSN) is slated to disclose fiscal second-quarter earnings early Monday, and investors will be looking to see if the company can post a fourth straight quarter of double-digit earnings growth.The meat, poultry, pork and prepared-foods company is projected to record a 5% increase in revenue to $8.84 billion.Consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share to leap 75% to 63 cents.Tyson's strong results over the past year have come despite challenges, including fresh outbreaks of bird and hog viruses in China and elsewhere.Not everyone is convinced Tyson can stay on the fast-growth track. BMO Capital Markets on Tuesday downgraded its rating from outperform (buy) to market perform (neutral). The bank cited what it considers Tyson's high valuation. Tyson stock has risen about 56% from a low of 27.33 on Nov. 4.On the company's first-quarter earnings call in late January, CEO Donnie Smith cautioned that Tyson faces headwinds this year.Smith told analysts that although consumers are becoming less defensive in spending, "I don't know of anyone who thinks that consumers will go back to their pre-2008 spending habits any time soon."Investors will look for clues on current pricing trends in the company's earnings report."Record high beef prices should continue through 2014," offsetting lower consumption, Smith said earlier this year. "Pork prices will also remain high due to lower supply. Chicken should continue to be the winner."Allianz Global Investors analyst Bryan Agbabian said in a report Wednesday that Tyson is a solid play on the increase in demand for chickens in the U.S. and globally, especially in China, the world's largest consumer market."Tyson is developing an in-country, in-China integrated production of chicken so that Tyson can then sell to not only the local market there, but also to the U.S.-based restaurants that are doing business there such as (Yum Brands (YUM)-owned) Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonald's (MCD)," Agbabian said in the report.Tyson shares were up nearly 1% in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market. Its stock price hit an all-time high 44.01 on March 31 and has consolidated since in sync with a market correction.Among other large meat producers, highly rated Hormel Foods (HRL) was unchanged. Hormel sports a 92 IBD Composite Rating, which means it has outperformed 92% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Fresh and frozen chicken products-maker Sanderson Farms (SAFM) climbed more than 2%. It boasts a 97 Composite Rating.Prepared- and fresh-chicken company Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) jumped 6% on bullish comments by CEO Bill Lovette during an earnings call with analysts Thursday.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar
The stock market finished lower Friday for the fifth time in the last seven sessions, ending the month of January with losses.

The Nasdaq ended down 0.5%, although it almost got back to even around midday. The S&P 500 shed 0.7%, and the Dow industrials 0.9%. Volume on both exchanges was higher than on Thursday, according to unconfirmed figures.
Friday's action concluded the first down month for the major indexes since August. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 5.3% in January, the S&P 500 was off 3.6% and the Nasdaq trimmed 1.7%.
Economic data due out Monday include the closely watched ISM manufacturing report, construction spending and auto sales.
Yum Brands (YUM) and Advanced Energy (AEIS) are two significant companies reporting earnings Monday after the close.

In the stock market today, Amazon (AMZN) was among the biggest losers. It tumbled 11%, slipping well below its 50-day line. Late Thursday, the e-commerce company missed Q4 views and gave a weak Q1 sales outlook.

But Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) rallied 12% gain in heavy volume, gapping past the 548.24 early buy point of a flat base after its Q4 sales beat estimates. Google (GOOG) advanced 4% to a new high in triple normal trade despite reporting mixed Q4 results late Thursday. Stocks continued to hold near session highs late Tuesday, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 on pace for their sixth straight gains.
The Nasdaq was up 1.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 rose 0.6% each. Volume was again running sharply higher across the board in the stock market today.

In leading stocks, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) jumped nearly 6% in active trading, putting it just below its 50-day moving average. The casino operator will report Q1 earnings Wednesday after the close. Sands recently found support at its 40-week moving average.

Zillow (Z) bounced back from earlier weakness and rose 4% to an all-time high in fast trade. It was off by 1% after being downgraded to fairly valued from buy at CRT Capital. The upside reversal puts the stock 15% past a 93.17 buy point from a handle. According to a report released today from Zillow, home prices in more than 1,000 U.S. cities are expected to hit record highs by next year.

Micron Technology (MU) extended its recent win streak, rising 3% to its best levels in nearly 12 years. The stock cleared a 25.78 buy point in a late-stage consolidation. After losing money in the past two years, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see it turning a profit of $3.02 a share this year.

On the downside, Allison Transmission (ALSN) dropped 4% but appeared to find support at its 50-day line. Late Monday, the company announced the sale of 25 million shares by investment funds connected with The Carlyle Group (CG) and Onex Corp. Last week, the stock briefly cleared a 31.37 buy point from a flat base.

Amgen (AMGN), Cree (CREE), Gilead Sciences (GILD), Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Packaging Corp. of America (PKG), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Super Micro Computer (SMCI), VMware (VMW) and Yum Brands (YUM) are a few notable companies reporting earnings after the close.Stocks continued to hold near session highs late Tuesday, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 on pace for their sixth straight gains.The Nasdaq was up 1.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 rose 0.6% each. Stocks shook off premarket uncertainty to grab early gains in firm trade Tuesday.
The Nasdaq led with a 0.6% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.3% each. Volume ticked up 5% on the Nasdaq and jumped 20% on the NYSE, compared with Monday's opening action.

The jumped in with both feet Tuesday after Monday's quiet start to the week. Stocks as diverse as Harley-Davidson (HOG), Netflix (NFLX) and Allergan (AGN) led the S&P 500. On the Dow, Home Depot (HD), Travelers (TRV) and Caterpillar (CAT) were all up more than 1%.

The Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index rose 0.6% month-over-month for February. That was up from January's number, a 0.4% gain after a slight downward revision. Analysts had projected a 0.3% increase.

Existing home sales eased a notch, according to the National Association of Realtors, moving at an annualized pace of 4.59 million in March, a fraction below February's 4.6 million pace but better than the 4.56 million forecast.
Leading stocks were off to a healthy start, with more than four-in-five of the IBD 50 members climbing at the starting bell. Drugmakers topped the list.

Allergan was the uncontested leader, up 15% after a joint offer from Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) valued the company at $46 billion. The Irvine, Calif.-based maker of Botox and various eye-care products was extended before Tuesday's advance, after a rebound from back above its 50-day moving average.
Valeant, also an IBD 50 issue, gained 4%. Valeant is in the second week of an advance off an April 8 low, correcting 25% between February and the first week of April.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) riffed off a 5% gain, apparently fueled by speculation that Allergan could attempt to avoid a takeover through an acquisition of its own. A Jefferies report named Jazz and Shire Pharmaceuticals (SHPG) as possible takeover targets for Allergan. Jazz is just creeping above its 10-week line, attempting to climb the right side of a consolidation. Shire shares rose 4%.

The expression "you can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink it" illustrates a key point: Effective leadership is proportional to inspiring willing and engaged followers. "As a leader, you'll never accomplish anything big if you try to do it alone. Your role is to unleash the power of people working together," David Novak, CEO of Yum Brands (YUM) and author of "Taking People With You," told IBD." Tips on doing just that:
• Share the outlook. Do your people know what success looks like for your business? So asks Erika Andersen, author of "Leading So People Will Follow."

Tell your people about your vision of success, she said: "What will your business or group look, feel and act like two years from now, or three? What will you be focused on and accomplishing? People want leaders who can articulate and guide them toward a compelling and inclusive future."

• Be resolute. No leader "ever accomplishes much by starting out with the 'maybe' attitude," Novak said. "Successful leaders recognize the first responsibility is to define reality and create a shared vision."
• Provide tools. Novak, whose firm oversees Pizza Hut and KFC, says leaders must back their plan by putting the right resources in place.
"This says to your team you really care about getting it done vs. giving it lip service," he said.

• Be courageous. Ineffective leaders often evade or blame others rather than taking responsibility. "When you make a mistake, do you apologize?," Andersen said. "The next time you stumble, say you're sorry and what you'll do differently going forward." This creates loyalty and followers.
• Demonstrate generosity. Do it with more than money.
Try giving others credit for a job well done, Andersen said: "Reflect on how you handle those things, and think about specific ways you can share that wealth."

• Show trust. "Don't make promises you can't keep," Andersen said. "Don't talk about one employee to others. Don't shade the truth. Remember that when you're the leader, people are watching everything you do to see if it lines up with what you say."
• Listen and act. Novak said hearing those you lead is "the most powerful way to motivate your people." Take what they tell you seriously, or they will lack commitment.

• Know your people. By getting inside the heads of those you lead, "you'll have the best chance of motivating them to help you achieve big things," Novak said. "I always ask: 'What perceptions, habits and beliefs do I need to change, build or reinforce to take people with me?'"
• Define your culture. People want to work in organizations that inspire them, Novak says. How a leader conducts himself greatly influences that.
He asked: "What sort of values are you projecting? What kind of atmosphere are you creating? Does it motivate your team to come to work every day feeling supported and appreciated?"
Novak said there's a "tangible difference in results between people working toward a goal because they're being paid to do it vs. working toward a goal because it is a rewarding experience."

• Be complete. Human beings are wired from ancient times to look for certain qualities in leaders, Andersen said: "On an almost instinctive level, we still take that decision very seriously. We need to see those time-tested qualities in a leader before we'll fully sign up."

Doing that gives people the best chance of becoming the best leader they're capable of being, she said, "the kind of leader people look to and say, 'I'm with you — let's go.'"The expression "you can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink it" illustrates a key point: Effective leadership is proportional to inspiring willing and engaged followers. Analysts expect Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) to deliver its biggest earnings gain in a year-and-a-half when the restaurant operator reports fourth-quarter results after the close Thursday. Chipotle, which has logged double-digit sales and profit growth in all but one quarter over the last three years, is expected to post Q4 EPS of $2.53, up 30% from a year earlier. If…

Based in Louisville, Ky., Yum Brands (YUM) might be regarded as a China-based company if you look only at revenue. Through 2006, America provided the biggest revenue footprint for the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell. In 2007, the international side edged ahead of the U.S. segment. In 2010, China alone passed the U.S. in generating revenue…

China is a big deal to Yum Brands International (YUM) as that's where it gets more than 40% of its sales and about half of operating profit.The operator of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell is now targeting India as its next key market. India is the world's second most populous market and its economy is expected to grow 6% this fiscal year through June, per the World Bank. The estimate, though, was lowered Oct. 10 from an earlier 6.9% projection.The company recently said it would spend $100 million in the next four to five years to expand its Indian operations. Yum Brands is targeting 1,000 restaurants by 2015. It currently has about 500, of which 101 were opened in 2011."India is at the same point China was before it took off, in terms of macroeconomic parameters such as per capita income and export as a percentage of GDP," Niren Chaudhary, president of Yum India, told Business Week.In Q1, Yum made India its own reporting segment. Quarterly sales in India grew 29% to 34% in the past three quarters, but still accounted for less than 1% of total revenue."We are laying the foundation for this business to have leading brands in every significant category in India including KFC, Pizza Casual Dining, Pizza Hut Home Service, and Taco Bell," said CEO David Novak in Yum's Q3 conference call. "We expect this business to have a substantial impact on Yum's profit growth in the future."Yum Brands has posted higher earnings each year since its founding as Tricon Global Restaurants in 1997. It has a three-year earnings growth rate of 14%. Its three-year Earnings Stability Factor is 1, signaling a rock-steady stream of income.Analysts see profit rising 14% to $3.28 a share this year.Besides stable growth, the restaurant giant rewards shareholders with dividends. It currently pays $1.34 a share, which works out to a yield of about 1.9%. Although its yield is among the lowest for companies in the Retail-Restaurants groups, Yum is one of the better-rated firms.The company last boosted its payout in September by 18% — the eighth straight double-digit increase. Its dividend has more than doubled in the past five years.Yum Brands is building the right side of a cup base.

Dunkin' Brands' (DNKN) Dunkin Donuts face-lift and expansion at home and overseas are seen vaulting earnings higher for at least the next few years, sending the stock to a new intraday high. Miller Tabak analysts said in a note Monday that they expect the expanded DDPerks rewards program to boost traffic and plans to remodel its restaurants to provide a…

In the global fast food arena, Yum Brands (YUM) continues to make its mark as export leader in the business of greasy, convenient, finger-lickin' casual American cuisine. After Tuesday's market close, the franchiser of the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC chains posted a 14% increase in third-quarter revenue to $3.27 billion. That's faster than the 9% sales increase seen…
When a stock undercuts the low of a previous base, the count is reset.
This is important because a stock breaking out of a first- or second-stage base has a much better chance of success than those clearing a later-stage pattern.
In October, Yum Brands (YUM) shaped a double bottom with handle that undercut the low of a flat base completed in late June. The action established the double bottom as a first-stage base.
The middle peak plus 10 cents — 55.80 in this case — is usually the buy point in a double bottom. But the handle offered a higher buy point at 56.05.

Volume and sometimes market conditions determine which entry becomes actionable. When Yum cleared the middle peak (before the handle was formed), the uptrend was under pressure and strong volume was absent.
When Yum cleared the handle, the market was in a correction and volume was again inadequate.
At this point, what was left? The left-side high plus 10 cents — 57.85 or up to 60.74 with the 5% chase limit — became a possibility.

For a month, Yum danced above and below the buy range without convincing volume. On Jan. 11, with the market in a confirmed uptrend and the stock still in the 5% buy zone, Yum broke out in 85% greater volume.
From the maximum allowed buy at 60.74, Yum advanced 23% in a little more than three months.
Doing nothing is the hardest thing for some investors to do. Yum worked, but an investor needed to wait for the right conditions.
Since late April, Yum has been consolidating. The stock lost its 50-day line but found support at its 200-day line. The correction is 16% deep, which is acceptable.
Yum needs to finish shaping a stage-two base. Once again, doing nothing is the course for now.
Yum's chains include Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell. The annual dividend yield is 1.8%.
Earnings grew in the 13% to 17% level in the past six years.
